This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Dickey_Betts","to":"Dickey Betts"}],"pages":{"1970439":{"pageid":1970439,"ns":0,"title":"Dickey Betts","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American  guitarist, singer and songwriter (1943\u20132024)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Dickey Betts\n| image             = Dickey Betts 1978 (cropped).jpg\n| caption           = Betts in 1978\n| image_size        = \n| birth_name        = Forrest Richard Betts\n| alias             = {{hlist|Dickey Betts|The Ramblin' Man}}\n| birth_date        = {{birth date|1943|12|12}}\n| birth_place       = [[West Palm Beach, Florida]], U.S.\n| death_date        = {{death date and age|2024|4|18|1943|12|12}}\n| death_place       = [[Osprey, Florida]], U.S.\n| instrument        = {{hlist|Guitar|vocals|[[dobro]]}}\n| genre             = {{hlist|[[Rock music|Rock]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[blues music|blues]]|[[jazz]]|[[Southern rock]]|[[jam band]]}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|composer|guitarist}}\n| years_active      = 1960\u20132021\n| label             = \n| current_member_of = Dickey Betts Band\n| past_member_of    = {{hlist|[[The Allman Brothers Band]]|Dickey Betts & Great Southern|[[Betts, Hall, Leavell and Trucks]]}}\n| website           = {{URL|dickeybetts.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Forrest Richard Betts''' (December 12, 1943 \u2013 April 18, 2024) was an American guitarist, singer, songwriter, composer and founding member of [[the Allman Brothers Band]]. He initially shared the band's signature dual [[lead guitar]] roles with band founder [[Duane Allman]], and assumed the solo lead after Allman's death in October of 1971.  As both a singer and composer as well, he was central to the group's greatest commercial success in the mid-1970s and was the writer and vocalist on the Allmans' hit single \"[[Ramblin' Man (The Allman Brothers Band song)|Ramblin' Man]]\". \n\nEarly in his career Betts was best noted for collaboration with Duane Allman,<ref name=Tdrozodowski>{{cite web|url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/Come%20and%20Go%20Blues_%20The%20Incredi|title=Come and Go Blues: The Incredible Guitarists of the Allman Brothers|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100126202416/http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/Come%20and%20Go%20Blues_%20The%20Incredi|archive-date=January 26, 2010}}</ref> the twosome introducing melodic twin guitar harmony and counterpoint, which, according to ''Guitar World'' \"rewrote the rules for how two rock guitarists can work together, completely scrapping the traditional rhythm/lead roles to stand toe to toe\".<ref name=\"GW July 2009\">{{cite magazine|title=The Allman Brothers Band: The Road Goes on Forever|magazine=Guitar World|date=July 20, 2009|url=http://www.guitarworld.com/article/the_allman_brothers_band_the_road_goes_on_forever|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202053024/http://www.guitarworld.com/article/the_allman_brothers_band_the_road_goes_on_forever|archive-date=February 2, 2010}}</ref> Betts initially gained renown for his epic [[instrumental]], \"[[In Memory of Elizabeth Reed]]\", from the Band's second album, ''[[Idlewild South]]'', followed by his striking guitar duet-driven \"[[Blue Sky (song)|Blue Sky]]\", which not only was his first band vocal but signaled a dramatic new sound and potential direction for it.  \n\nIn the wake of Duane's death the group indeed followed both Betts' musical direction and band leadership, exploding into commercial success in 1973 upon the introduction of the [[Country music|Country]]-influenced ''[[Brothers and Sisters (album)|Brothers and Sisters]]'', and the chart success of its catchy Betts-written hits, exuberant \"Ramblin' Man\" and the melodic instrumental \"[[Jessica (instrumental)|Jessica]]\".\n\nThe band went through a hiatus in the late 1970s, during which time Betts, like many of the other band members, pursued a solo career and side projects under such names as Great Southern and The Dickey Betts Band.  The Allman Brothers reformed in 1979, with [[Dan Toler]] taking the second guitar role alongside Betts.  In 1982, it broke up a second time, during which break Betts formed the group [[Betts, Hall, Leavell and Trucks]], which lasted until 1984.  A third reformation occurred in 1989, with [[Warren Haynes]] then joining Betts on guitar. \n\nBetts was ousted from the band in 2000 over a conflict regarding his continued drug and alcohol abuse; he never played with them again, nor would he appear with other former band members for reunions or side projects. With the death of Betts on April 18, 2024, Jai Johanny \"[[Jaimoe]]\" Johanson is the last living founding member of the Allman Brothers Band.\n\nHe was inducted with the band into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 1995<ref name=\":0\">{{cite web |url=http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/the-allman-brothers-band/ |title=The Allman Brothers Band: inducted in 1995 &#124; The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum |publisher=Rockhall.com |access-date=February 28, 2012 |archive-date=July 1, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120701000000/http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/the-allman-brothers-band/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and also won a best rock performance [[Grammy Award]] with the band for \"Jessica\" in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=1995&genre=All|title=1995 Grammy Award Winners|publisher=Grammy.com|access-date=November 18, 2012|archive-date=September 23, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923073524/http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=1995&genre=All|url-status=live}}</ref> Betts was ranked No. 58 on ''Rolling Stone''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time list in 2003, and No. 61 on the list published in 2011.<ref name=RS931>{{cite magazine |title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time |magazine=Rolling Stone |issue=931 |date=September 22, 2003 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231/dickey-betts-19691231 |access-date=August 26, 2017 |archive-date=July 13, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713073551/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231/dickey-betts-19691231 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=RS1145>{{cite magazine|title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time|magazine=Rolling Stone|issue=1145|date=November 23, 2011|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/dickey-betts-19691231|access-date=August 26, 2017|archive-date=July 18, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718093137/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/dickey-betts-19691231|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\n{{expand section|date=September 2024}}\n\nBetts was born in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]], on December 12, 1943, and raised in [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lcwXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT69|title=Skydog: The Duane Allman Story|first=Randy|last=Poe|date=August 1, 2008|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|isbn=9781617134876}}</ref><ref name=NFMHOF>{{cite web|last1=Fitzgerald|first1=Michael|title=Betts, Dickey|url=http://nfmhof.com/2008/08/13/betts-dickey|publisher=North Florida Music Hall of Fame|access-date=August 3, 2014|date=August 13, 2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108154840/http://nfmhof.com/2008/08/13/betts-dickey|archive-date=November 8, 2014}}</ref> He grew up in a musical family listening to [[traditional bluegrass]], [[country music]] and [[Western swing]]. He started playing ukulele at the age of five and, as his hands got bigger, moved on to mandolin, banjo, and guitar.\n\n==Career==\nBy the age of sixteen Betts was feeling the need for something \"a little faster\", and played in a series of rock bands on the Florida circuit, up the East Coast and into the Midwest.  In 1967 he formed the Second Coming in Florida with [[Berry Oakley]]. According to its composer, [[Rick Derringer]], the group called the Jokers referenced in \"[[Rock and Roll, Hoochie Koo]]\" was one of Betts' early groups of that name.<ref>Scott Freeman, ''Midnight Riders'', pp. 41\u201342</ref>\n\n=== Early Allman Brothers Band years ===\nIn 1969, [[Duane Allman]], a veteran of the South's \"Chitlin' Circuit\" of roadhouses and small local venues who'd gone on to form several bands with recording contracts, was casting for talent to build another around.  A successful session player, he'd gained a deal with [[Southern soul]] impresario [[Phil Walden]], who planned to back a [[power trio]] featuring Allman. The ensuing Allman Brothers Band eventually grew to six members, including Duane's brother, organist, vocalist, and composer [[Gregg Allman|Gregg]], Betts, and bassist [[Berry Oakley]].{{cn|date=April 2024}} Duane, who later worked with famed British guitar virtuoso [[Eric Clapton]], earning notoriety for his standout playing on \"[[Layla (song)|Layla]]'', the collaboration's signature hit, once said with typical modesty, \"I'm the famous guitar player, but Dickey is the good one.\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Alex |title=Dickey Betts, Fiery Guitarist With Allman Brothers Band, Dies at 80 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/18/arts/music/dickey-betts-dead.html |work=The New York Times |date=April 18, 2024 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |archive-date=April 19, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240419202131/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/18/arts/music/dickey-betts-dead.html |url-status=live }}</ref> \n\nAfter Allman's death in October 1971, Betts became the band's sole lead guitarist (with a pianist bringing the group back up to six members) and took on a greater singing, composing, and leadership role. Rushed into the role, he practiced [[slide guitar]] intensively in order to be able to cover the majority of Duane's parts. He wrote \"[[Jessica (Allman Brothers Band song)|Jessica]]\", inspired by his young daughter Jessica,<ref>{{Cite book|title=One Way Out: The Inside History of the Allman Brothers Band|first=Alan|last=Paul|year=2014|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-1250040497}}</ref>and the Allmans' biggest commercial hit, \"[[Ramblin' Man (Allman Brothers Band song)|Ramblin' Man]]\",<ref>{{cite web|url= https://rockcellarmagazine.com/dickey-betts-dies-allman-brothers-band-obituary/|title=Dickey Betts, Allman Brothers Co-Founder Who Wrote \"Ramblin' Man,\" \"Jessica\" and More, Dies at 80|publisher=Rockcellarmagazine.com|date=April 18, 2024|accessdate=April 20, 2024}}</ref> for the Band's breakout commercial success, ''[[Brothers and Sisters (album)|Brothers and Sisters]]'', in 1974.\n\n=== Solo career and later work ===\n[[File:Dickey Betts (1974).jpg|thumb|Betts in 1974|244x244px]]\nBetts's first solo album, ''[[Highway Call]]'', was released in 1974 and featured fiddle player [[Vassar Clements]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Highway Call \u2013 Dickey Betts, Richard Betts &#124; Album &#124; AllMus |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/highway-call-mw0000199122 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221022115912/https://www.allmusic.com/album/highway-call-mw0000199122 |archive-date=October 22, 2022 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> After the Allman Brothers fell apart in 1976, Betts released more albums, starting with ''[[Dickey Betts & Great Southern (album)|Dickey Betts & Great Southern]]'' in 1977, which included the song \"Bougainvillea\", co-written with future Hollywood star and then Florida transplant [[Don Johnson]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dickey Betts & Great Southern \u2013 Dickey Betts & Great Southe |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/dickey-betts-great-southern-mw0000602906 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909051526/https://www.allmusic.com/album/dickey-betts-great-southern-mw0000602906 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> In 1978 he released an album, ''[[Atlanta's Burning Down]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Atlanta's Burning Down \u2013 Dickey Betts &#124; Album &#124; AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/atlantas-burning-down-mw0000049199 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221020100419/https://www.allmusic.com/album/atlantas-burning-down-mw0000049199 |archive-date=October 20, 2022 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>\n\nThe Allman Brothers reformed in 1979 for the album ''[[Enlightened Rogues]]'', with two members of Great Southern replacing Allman Brothers members who were unwilling to participate in the reunion: guitar player [[Dan Toler]] for pianist [[Chuck Leavell]], and bassist [[David Goldflies]] for bassist [[Lamar Williams]]. Several albums and personnel changes followed, until declining record and concert ticket sales, personnel issues, and management problems led the group to disband again in 1982.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 27, 2014 |title=History of the Allman Brothers Band |url=https://ultimateclassicrock.com/allman-brothers-band-history/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231003172943/https://ultimateclassicrock.com/allman-brothers-band-history/ |archive-date=October 3, 2023 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Ultimateclassicrock.com}}</ref>\n\nBetts formed his own band, [[Betts, Hall, Leavell and Trucks]], where he was co-frontman along with former [[Wet Willie]] singer, saxophone, and harmonica player [[Jimmy Hall]]. Despite earning good notices, the group was unable to secure a recording contract and disbanded in 1984.<ref>{{Cite book |last1=Leavell |first1=Chuck |title=Between Rock And A Home Place |last2=Craig |first2=J. Marshall |publisher=Evergreen Arts |year=2004 |isbn=0-86554-975-3 |location=Dry Branch, Georgia |pages=260\u2013264}} For the ending year, see {{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/101951915/lexington-herald-leader/ | title=David Goldflies' jazz vision | author-first=Walter | author-last=Tunis | newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader | date=April 21, 1991 | pages=C1, C7 | via=Newspapers.com | access-date=May 21, 2022 | archive-date=May 20, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220520105254/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/101951915/lexington-herald-leader/ | url-status=live }}</ref> Betts  returned to his solo career performing live at smaller venues, and released the album ''Pattern Disruptive'' in 1989. When a one-off reunion tour was proposed in support of the Allman Brothers' ''[[Dreams (The Allman Brothers Band album)|Dreams]]'' box set, released in 1989 to commemorate the band's 20th anniversary, Betts's solo band again supplied the Allman Brothers' other lead guitarist, [[Warren Haynes]]. The success of the one-off tour resulted in a permanent reunion, which absorbed Betts's energies for the remainder of the 1990s. This band line-up released three studio albums between 1990 and 1994 and won the praise of the critics.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Elliott, Mike |date=July 20, 2020 |title=The Allman Brothers Band's 'Seven Turns' Turns 30 {{!}} Anniversary Retrospective |url=https://albumism.com/features/the-allman-brothers-band-seven-turns-turns-30-anniversary-retrospective |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220703150058/https://albumism.com/features/the-allman-brothers-band-seven-turns-turns-30-anniversary-retrospective |archive-date=July 3, 2022 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Albumism}}</ref>\n[[File:Dickey Betts Pistoia Blues Festival 2008.jpg|left|thumb|243x243px|Betts in 2008]]\nBetts was replaced on numerous Allman Brothers tour dates throughout the mid-to-late 1990s, for what were reported in the media as \"personal reasons\". While remaining active as a touring band, the Allman Brothers did not release another album of studio material after 1994's ''[[Where It All Begins]]'' for nine years, until ''[[Hittin' the Note]]'' in 2003. In 1994, Haynes and Allmans bassist Allen Woody formed [[Gov't Mule]] with former Dickey Betts Band drummer Matt Abts as a side project, and left the Allman Brothers for Gov't Mule full-time in 1997. Betts' last show with the Allman Brothers was at the Music Midtown Festival in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], on May 7, 2000.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Roger Catlin |date=May 25, 2000 |title=BETTS IS ANGRY AS ALLMANS DUMP HIM FROM TOUR |url=https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2000-05-25-0005251999-story.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190720154255/https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2000-05-25-0005251999-story.html |archive-date=July 20, 2019 |access-date=February 3, 2021 |website=Courant.com}}</ref>\n\nA breaking point was reached after that show and before the launch of the band's Summer Campaign Tour when the remaining original Allman Brothers members \u2013 Gregg Allman, Butch Trucks, and Jaimoe \u2013 suspended Betts.<ref name=\"ew\">{{Cite magazine |last=Reese |first=Lori |date=May 18, 2000 |title=Brothers in Law |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,85221,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021145418/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,85221,00.html |archive-date=October 21, 2012 |access-date=June 16, 2011 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref> According to Betts, the band told him (reportedly via [[fax]]) to \"get clean\" (from alcohol and/or drugs). \n\nHe was temporarily replaced for the 2000 tour by [[Jimmy Herring]], formerly of the [[Aquarium Rescue Unit]]. When Betts filed suit against the other three original Allmans, the separation turned into a permanent divorce.<ref>{{cite book |last=Allman |first=Gregg |title=My Cross To Bear |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2012}}{{p.|340}}</ref> Betts re-formed the Dickey Betts Band and toured that same summer. The band reassumed the name Dickey Betts & Great Southern and added Betts' son Duane (named after Duane Allman) on lead guitar. In 2005, Betts released the DVD ''Live from the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Back Where It All Begins: Live at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame [Video] |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/back-where-it-all-begins-live-at-the-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-video--mw0001020587 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=AllMusic}}</ref>\n\nAlthough they had been separated personally and as musical bandmates for over 15 years, Betts and Gregg Allman became reconciled before Allman's death in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Ferris, Jedd |date=December 13, 2018 |title=ee Dickey Betts Talk Gregg Allman Reconciliation, Return to Touring |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-dan-rather-768633/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230606131632/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-dan-rather-768633/ |archive-date=June 6, 2023 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Rolling Stone}}</ref>\n\nBetts' final album release was ''Dickey Betts & Great Southern Official Bootleg Vol. 1'' (2021), a two-CD live album of performances from the 2000s.<ref>{{Cite news |date=April 24, 2021 |title=Dickey Betts Announces 'Dickey Betts & Great Southern Official Bootleg Vol. 1' |url=https://dickeybetts.com/dickey-betts-announces-dickey-betts-great-southern-official-bootleg-vol-1/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109192901/https://dickeybetts.com/dickey-betts-announces-dickey-betts-great-southern-official-bootleg-vol-1/ |archive-date=January 9, 2024 |access-date=April 18, 2024 |work=Dickey Betts}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nBetts was married five times, last to Donna, in 1989.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dickey-betts-the-lost-allman-brother-121021/|title=Dickey Betts Looks Back: The Lost Allman Brother on Regret, Retirement|last=Browne|first=David|date=November 22, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=February 18, 2020|archive-date=February 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200218202725/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dickey-betts-the-lost-allman-brother-121021/|url-status=live}}</ref> He had four children: Kimberly, Christy, Jessica, and [[Duane Betts|Duane]]. Christy is married to [[Frank Hannon]] of the band [[Tesla (band)|Tesla]]. Jessica is the namesake of Betts' [[Jessica (instrumental) |instrumental]]. Duane, named for Betts' former bandmate Duane Allman, is also a musician and performed and recorded with his father, and in a band together with Gregg Allman's son Devon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180809/duane-betts-talks-album-with-devon-allman-dickey-betts-band-live-cddvd-and-aug-15-sarasota-show|title=Duane Betts talks album with Devon Allman, Dickey Betts Band live CD/DVD and Aug. 15 Sarasota show|last=Tatangelo|first=Wade|website=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|language=en|access-date=February 18, 2020|archive-date=September 29, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190929154356/https://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180809/duane-betts-talks-album-with-devon-allman-dickey-betts-band-live-cddvd-and-aug-15-sarasota-show|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nBetts was a Florida native, born in [[West Palm Beach]]; though he resided briefly in Georgia during the formative years of the Allman Brothers Band, he lived in the [[Sarasota metropolitan area]] for most of his life.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Liberatore|url=http://www.marinij.com/marinnews/ci_20957654/lib-at-large-duane-betts-and-legacy-allman|title=Lib at Large: Duane Betts and the legacy of the Allman Brothers|work=[[Marin Independent Journal]]|publisher=Marinij.com|date=June 29, 2012|access-date=July 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714210135/http://www.marinij.com/marinnews/ci_20957654/lib-at-large-duane-betts-and-legacy-allman|archive-date=July 14, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n===Death===\nIn August 2018, the 74-year old Betts suffered a mild stroke and had to cancel tour dates with his Dickey Betts Band. He was taken to the hospital and was in a critical but stable condition at a Florida hospital, following an accident at his home in [[Osprey, Florida]]. On September 20, 2018,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/dickey-betts-to-undergo-brain-surgery-following-accident/ar-BBNzI1x|title=Dickey Betts to Undergo Brain Surgery Following Accident|website=www.msn.com|language=en-US|access-date=September 20, 2018|archive-date=September 20, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920084332/https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/dickey-betts-to-undergo-brain-surgery-following-accident/ar-BBNzI1x|url-status=live}}</ref> he successfully underwent surgery to relieve swelling on his brain. In a statement posted on his website, Betts and his family said the \"outpouring of support from all over the world has been overwhelming and amazing. We are so appreciative.\"<ref>{{cite web|author=Tatangelo, Wade|url=https://eu.news-journalonline.com/story/news/state/2018/09/22/dickey-betts-surgery-success-in/10366942007/|title=Dickey Betts' surgery a 'success' in Sarasota|publisher=The Daytona Bach News Journal|date=September 18, 2018|accessdate=April 20, 2024}}</ref>\n\nBetts died from cancer and [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] at his home in Osprey, Florida, on April 18, 2024, at the age of 80.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dickey Betts, Allman Brothers Band Singer-Guitarist, Dead at 80|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-band-dead-727523/|last=Browne|first=David|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=April 18, 2024|access-date=April 18, 2024|archive-date=April 18, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240418154924/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-band-dead-727523/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Instagram |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/C56GswQuAKR/ |access-date=April 18, 2024 |website=www.instagram.com |archive-date=April 18, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240418160858/https://www.instagram.com/p/C56GswQuAKR/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{See also|The Allman Brothers Band discography}}\n\n* Use [[Special:ApiFeatureUsage]] to see usage of deprecated features by your application."},"revisions":{"*":"Because \"rvslots\" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Robert_Ellis_Orrall","to":"Robert Ellis Orrall"}],"pages":{"11310263":{"pageid":11310263,"ns":0,"title":"Robert Ellis Orrall","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Robert Ellis Orrall\n| image            = \n| background       = solo_singer\n| alias            = Bob Something\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1955|5|4}}\n| origin           = [[Winthrop, Massachusetts]], U.S.\n| instrument       = {{flatlist|\n*[[Vocals]]\n*[[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]]\n*[[guitar]]\n}}\n| website          = {{URL|www.robertellisorrall.com}}\n| genre            = {{flatlist|\n*[[Rock music|Rock]]\n*[[indie rock]]\n*[[Country music|country]]\n*[[Pop music|pop]]\n}}\n| occupation       = {{flatlist|\n*Singer\n*songwriter\n*record producer\n}}\n| years_active     = 1980\u2013present\n| label            = {{flatlist|\n*[[RCA Records|RCA]]\n*Infinity Cat (solo)\n*[[Giant Records (Warner Bros. subsidiary label)|Giant]] (in Orrall & Wright)\n*[[Sony]]\n*Plastic350\n}}\n| past_member_of = [[Orrall & Wright]]\n}}\n'''Robert Ellis Orrall''' (born May 4, 1955) is an American singer, songwriter, and record producer. Signed to RCA Records in 1980, Orrall debuted that year with the album \"Fixation\". His first Top 40 single was \"I Couldn't Say No\", a duet with [[Carlene Carter]]. By 1990, Orrall had found success as a songwriter, having penned Number One singles for [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]] and [[Clay Walker]]. He returned to RCA in 1991 and charted the singles \"Boom! It Was Over\" (#19) and \"A Little Bit of Her Love\" (#31), from his first [[country music]] album, ''[[Flying Colors (Robert Ellis Orrall album)|Flying Colors]]''. Orrall then joined frequent songwriting partner [[Curtis Wright]] in the CMA-nominated duo [[Orrall & Wright]], recording one more album and charting two singles. They split up in 1994, however, and Orrall returned to his solo career, writing singles for [[Reba McEntire]], [[Taylor Swift]], and [[Lindsay Lohan]], as well as producing records for Swift, [[Be Your Own Pet]],  and [[Love and Theft (band)|Love and Theft]]. He also performs and records as an [[indie rock]] musician in the band Monkey Bowl.\n\n==Musical career==\n===Beginnings===\nBorn in [[Winthrop, Massachusetts]], Orrall got his musical start playing in various [[Boston, Massachusetts]], area clubs. He signed with RCA in 1980 as a rock artist. His three RCA albums, ''Fixation'', ''Special Pain'' and ''Contain Yourself'' were supported by band mates Kook Lawry on guitar, Don Walden on bass, David Stefanelli on drums and [[Brian Maes]] on keys with tours opening for [[U2]], [[The Kinks]], and [[NRBQ]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://robertellisorrall.com/|title=Robert Ellis Orrall|website=Robertellisorrall.com}}</ref> Orrall's ''Special Pain'' also produced his first chart single in \"I Couldn't Say No\", a duet with [[Carlene Carter]] (also her first chart hit) which peaked in the Top 40 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref name=\"peer\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.peermusic.com/artistpage/Robert_Ellis_Orrall.html|title=Robert Ellis Orrall @ peermusic - The Independent Major|date=25 March 2002|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020325053836/http://www.peermusic.com/artistpage/Robert_Ellis_Orrall.html|access-date=27 January 2021|archive-date=2002-03-25}}</ref> Carter, like Orrall, would eventually become a country music star in her own right.\n\n===Nashville===\nOrrall eventually gained an interest in country music through such acts as [[Steve Earle]], [[Lyle Lovett]], and [[Foster & Lloyd]].<ref name=\"peer\"/> He then moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]],<ref name=\"oldies\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.oldies.com/artist-view/Robert-Ellis-Orrall.html|title=Robert Ellis Orrall|website=Oldies.com}}</ref> intending to use his songwriting and record producing skills.<ref name=\"peer\"/> One of his first cuts was [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]]'s \"[[Next to You, Next to Me]]\", which Orrall co-wrote with [[Curtis Wright]].<ref name=\"oldies\"/>\n\nShortly after his song topped the charts, Orrall's publisher BMG Music urged him to perform his songs at The Bluebird Cafe in Nashville. He was then offered a second record deal with RCA.<ref name=\"peer\"/> Titled ''[[Flying Colors (Robert Ellis Orrall album)|Flying Colors]]'', Orrall's first and only solo country album produced three charting singles, including a Top 20 in \"Boom! It Was Over\", as well as \"A Little Bit of Her Love\" and \"Every Day When I Get Home\". In 1993, [[Clay Walker]] reached Number One on the country charts with Orrall's \"[[What's It to You]]\", another Wright co-write.\n\n===Orrall & Wright===\n{{main|Orrall & Wright}}\nOrrall and Wright paired up in 1994, forming a duo known as [[Orrall & Wright]].<ref>[{{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p31126/biography|pure_url=yes}} AllMusic (((Curtis Wright > Biography)))]</ref><ref name=\"cmt\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472809/20030617/orrall_robert_ellis.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930041158/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1472809/20030617/orrall_robert_ellis.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=September 30, 2007|title=CMT.com : Robert Ellis Orrall : Robert Ellis Orrall Gets Personal in New Paintings, Albums|website=Cmt.com}}</ref> They recorded one album for [[Giant Records (Warner Bros. subsidiary label)|Giant Records]]. After charting two songs on the Billboard charts, \"She Loves Me Like She Means It\" and \"If You Could Say What I'm Thinking\", the duo was nominated for Duo of the Year by the [[Country Music Association]]. Orrall & Wright split up in 1994, and Orrall moved on to developing and producing new artists.\n\n===Late 1990s and 2000s===\nOrrall continued to write songs and produce records for other artists, including \"What If It's You\" for [[Reba McEntire]], \"Ultimate\"\" for [[Lindsay Lohan]], The Swing\" for [[James Bonamy]], as well as many cuts by [[Michael Peterson (singer)|Michael Peterson]]: the Number One hit \"[[From Here to Eternity (Michael Peterson song)|From Here to Eternity]]\". He also took up [[painting]], and holds one-man shows around Nashville.<ref name=\"cmt\"/> He is represented by Estel Gallery.\n\nIn 2002 Orrall and his two sons, Jake and Jamin, formed an independent rock label called [[Infinity Cat Recordings]]. One of the acts signed to that label is fictitious [[indie rock]] group Monkey Bowl, in which Orrall assumes the pseudonym Bob Something.<ref name=\"monkey\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.infinitycat.com/MonkeyBowl.htm|title=monkey bowl|website=Infinitycat.com|access-date=2007-05-19|archive-date=2007-05-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528031942/http://www.infinitycat.com/MonkeyBowl.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 2004, the group achieved media attention for its song \"Al Gore\".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://musicrowdemocrats.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=67|title=Music Row Democrats - Cut By Cut|date=8 December 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208213225/http://musicrowdemocrats.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=29&Itemid=67|access-date=27 January 2021|archive-date=2006-12-08}}</ref> Written by Orrall, the song features an appearance by former United States vice president [[Al Gore]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.commondreams.org/headlines06/0819-02.htm|title=In Nashville, Sounds of Political Uprising From the Left|website=Commondreams.com}}</ref> Among the acts on the label are [[JEFF the Brotherhood]], which is composed of Orrall's sons, Jamin and Jake.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nashvillescene.com/Stories/Arts/Music/2007/01/18/The_Cat_s_Out_of_the_Bag/index.shtml|title=Nashville Scene - The Cat's Out of the Bag|website=Nashvillescene.com|access-date=2007-05-19|archive-date=2007-05-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070504090718/http://www.nashvillescene.com/Stories/Arts/Music/2007/01/18/The_Cat_s_Out_of_the_Bag/index.shtml|url-status=dead}}</ref> Although Orrall does not write for bands on the label, he has occasionally engineered or mixed their albums, most recently grunge-pop trio [[Daddy Issues (band)|Daddy Issues]]' debut full-length ''Can We Still Hang''.<ref name=\"This City's Full\">{{cite web|url=http://www.thiscitysfull.com/TCF-Presents-Daddy-Issues |last=Brown |first=Kevin |title=TCF Presents Daddy Issues |website=Thiscitysfull.com|access-date=2010-03-25}}</ref>\n\nOrrall has continued writing for other artists in the 2000s, including [[Martina McBride]]'s 2010 single \"[[Wrong Baby Wrong]]\" and [[Ashton Shepherd]]'s 2011 single \"[[Look It Up (song)|Look It Up]]\". He also co-produced singer-songwriter [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[Taylor Swift (album)|self-titled debut album]] and her 2008 [[extended play]] ''[[Beautiful Eyes]]'', as well as [[Love and Theft (band)|Love and Theft]]'s 2009 album ''[[World Wide Open]]''. Overall, he has written more than 250 songs for other artists.<ref name=\"Tenten\">{{cite web |url=http://tentenmusic.com/writers/robertellisorrall.html |title=Ten Ten Music Group, Inc. - Robert Ellis Orrall |website=Tentenmusic.com |access-date=2010-03-25 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130141645/http://tentenmusic.com/writers/robertellisorrall.html |archive-date=2010-11-30 }}</ref> He contributed the title track to the Victor/SonyBMG album \"The Book Of Lies\", described as the \"first soundtrack for a book.\".<ref name=\"MTV\">{{cite web|url=http://splashpage.mtv.com/2008/08/21/listen-to-an-exclusive-track-from-the-book-of-lies/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008005814/http://splashpage.mtv.com/2008/08/21/listen-to-an-exclusive-track-from-the-book-of-lies/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 8, 2008 |title=Listen To An Exclusive Track From Brad Meltzer's 'The Book of Lies' |website=Splashpage.mtv.com |date=2008-08-21 |access-date=2010-03-25}}</ref> In 2010, he released \"Gravity\", which comes packaged with a free copy of \"Mistakes\", his 1998 autobiographical album lauded by the Washington Post.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-648871.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106100053/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-648871.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 6, 2012|title=Nashville's Man Without a Country; With Songwriter Robert Ellis Orrall's Little-Known 'Mistakes,' to Err Is Divine - The Washington Post &#124; HighBeam Research|date=November 6, 2012}}</ref> In 2012, he released another album from Monkey Bowl, \"Space,\"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://plastic350records.com/2012/09/15/monkey-bowls-space-is-out-of-this-world/|title=Protected Blog \u203a Log in|website=Plastic350records.com|access-date=2020-04-23|archive-date=2019-04-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190423092700/https://plastic350records.com/2012/09/15/monkey-bowls-space-is-out-of-this-world/|url-status=dead}}</ref> this time on Plastic 350 Records. In 2021, he released a new album, ''467 Surf and Gun Club'', which featured many members of his original band.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychedelicbabymag.com/2021/10/robert-ellis-orrall-interview-new-album-467-surf-and-gun-club.html|title=Robert Ellis Orrall Interview |website=[[It's Psychedelic Baby! Magazine]]|date=9 October 2021 }}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Albums===\n*''Sweet Nothing'' (REO)\n*''Big 12 Inch Single'' (Sail)\n*''Fixation'' (1981) (RCA)\n*''Special Pain'' (1983) (RCA)\n*''Contain Yourself'' (1984) (RCA)\n*''[[Flying Colors (Robert Ellis Orrall album)|Flying Colors]]'' (1993) (RCA)\n*''Plastic 350'' (2004) (Infinity Cat) as Monkey Bowl\n*\"Soon To Be A Major Motion Picture\" (2005) (Infinity Cat) as Steffle/Flanders\n*\"Art Circus\" (2006) (Infinity Cat) as Art Circus\n*''Ultimate'' (2008) (Infinity Cat) as Monkey Bowl\n*''The Book Of Lies'' (2008) (Victor/SonyBMG)\n*''Mistakes/Gravity\"'' (2010) (Plastic350)\n*''Space'' (2012) (Plastic350) as Monkey Bowl\n*''467 Surf and Gun Club'' (2021) (Fixation Records)\n\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Crystal_Bowersox","to":"Crystal Bowersox"}],"pages":{"26250151":{"pageid":26250151,"ns":0,"title":"Crystal Bowersox","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter and actress (born 1985)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name         = Crystal Bowersox\n| image        = Crystal Bowersox.jpg\n| caption      = Bowersox in 2010\n| birth_name   = Crystal Lynn Bowersox\n| birth_place  = [[Ottawa County, Ohio|Elliston, Ohio]], U.S.\n| birth_date   = {{birth date and age|1985|8|4}}\n| genre        = {{flatlist|\n* [[Rock music|Rock]]\n* [[indie folk]]\n* [[acoustic music|acoustic]]\n* [[blues music|blues]]\n* [[gospel music|gospel]]\n* [[soul music|soul]]\n* [[blues rock]]\n* [[country music|country]]\n}}\n| instrument   = {{flatlist|\n* [[Singing|Vocals]]\n* [[guitar]]\n* [[harmonica]]\n}}\n| occupation   = {{flatlist|\n* Singer\n* songwriter\n* actress\n}}\n| years_active = 2010\u2013present\n| label        = {{plainlist|\n* [[Jive Records|Jive]]\n* [[19 Entertainment|19]] (2010\u20132011)\n* [[Shanachie Records|Shanachie]] (2012\u20132013)\n* Mamasox (2013\u2013present)\n}}\n| website      = {{URL|crystalbowersox.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Crystal Lynn Bowersox''' (born August 4, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter and actress who was the runner-up on the [[American Idol (season 9)|ninth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]''. She was the first female finalist in three years.\n\nBowersox's debut album, ''[[Farmer's Daughter (album)|Farmer's Daughter]]'', was released on December 14, 2010 by [[Jive Records]]. Bowersox released her second album, ''[[All That for This]],'' on March 26, 2013.\n\n==Early life==\nBowersox and her twin brother, Karl,  were born in [[Ottawa County, Ohio|Elliston, Ohio]]<ref name=\"ChiTribune-04-28-10\">{{cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/2010/04/28/where-crystal-bowersox-comes-from/ |title=Where Crystal Bowersox comes from - tribunedigital-chicagotribune |publisher=Articles.chicagotribune.com |date=April 28, 2010|access-date=November 4, 2015|url-access=subscription}}</ref> to Kelly Lynn Bowersox (n\u00e9e Bowlander) and William Lester Bowersox.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://birth-records.mooseroots.com/l/12460879/Crystal-Lynn-Bowersox | title=Birth Record of Crystal Lynn Bowersox | publisher=MooseRoots | access-date=November 1, 2016 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Her parents divorced when she was two years old.<ref name=bio>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/crystal-bowersox-554918#early-life|work=Biography Channel|title=Crystal Bowersox: Songwriter, Singer, Television Personality|access-date=January 19, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202000225/http://www.biography.com/people/crystal-bowersox-554918#early-life|archive-date=February 2, 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> At age six, Bowersox was diagnosed with [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|type 1 diabetes]]. She attended [[Oak Harbor High School (Ohio)|Oak Harbor High School]] in [[Oak Harbor, Ohio]] and later attended the [[Toledo School for the Arts]] in [[Toledo, Ohio]].<ref name=\"ChiTribune-04-28-10\"/> She was in choir and played flute in the school marching band. Bowersox performed her first professional gig at the age of 10. She appeared at local bars in Toledo, most popularly Papa's Tavern, and The Village Idiot in [[Maumee, Ohio]].\n\nAt the age of seventeen, she moved to [[Chicago]], where she played music as a [[busker]] at train stations, including the Washington and Lake Redline stops. She frequented open mics, such as the In One Ear show at the [[Heartland Cafe]], and Uncommon Ground Clark and Grace, and Devon locations. She also played extensively in Chicago's Lakeview neighborhood.\n\nIn 2006, the Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs chose Bowersox to represent Chicago folk musicians in the [[Sister Cities]] program \"Experience Chicago\", held in [[Birmingham]]. In 2007, Bowersox traveled internationally on an independent small cafe tour, including [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Oaxaca City]], [[Ankara]] and [[Istanbul]]. She gave birth to a son, Anthony Levi Mason, in 2009;<ref name=bio/> according to Bowersox, his father left her six weeks into her pregnancy.{{citation needed|date=July 2023}}\n\n==''American Idol''==\nBowersox auditioned for ''American Idol'' in [[Chicago, Illinois]]. She sang \"[[Piece of My Heart]]\". Guest judge [[Shania Twain]] commented that she had a \"raw, natural talent.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=https://vancouversun.com/entertainment/Bowersox+Idol+idolize/3056262/story.html |title= Bowersox an Idol to idolize |author= Alex Strachan |publisher=[[The Vancouver Sun]] |date= May 21, 2010 |access-date= July 30, 2010}}</ref>\n\nOn March 2, 2010, Bowersox was hospitalized due to [[Diabetic ketoacidosis]] (DKA) from [[type 1 diabetes]], forcing a last minute switch in scheduling to give her extra time to recuperate. Bowersox confirmed the illness on the May 19, 2010 results show during an interview with host [[Ryan Seacrest]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cnmnewsnetwork.com/11618/crystal-bowersox-hospital-2010-american-idol-contestant-hospitalized-for-diabetes/ |title=Crystal Bowersox Hospital: 2010 American Idol Contestant Hospitalized for Diabetes? |author=Bella Horton |publisher=CNN |date=March 3, 2010 |access-date=March 25, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306130832/http://cnmnewsnetwork.com/11618/crystal-bowersox-hospital-2010-american-idol-contestant-hospitalized-for-diabetes/ |archive-date=March 6, 2010 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959174/crystal-bowersoxs-american-idol-future-uncertain |title=Crystal Bowersox's 'American Idol' Future Uncertain |agency=Associated Press |date=March 3, 2010 |access-date=March 25, 2010}}</ref> The men competed that day instead of the women. She sang the next day and impressed all of the judges.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/crystal-bowersox-wows-idol-judges/ |title=Crystal Bowersox Wows \"Idol\" Judges |agency=Associated Press |date=March 4, 2010 |access-date=March 25, 2010 |work=CBS News}}</ref>\n\nThe following week, her strong performance prompted [[Simon Cowell]] to state, \"Right now, you are the one everyone has to beat.\"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1633573/20100309/story.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100312132906/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1633573/20100309/story.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=March 12, 2010 |title=Crystal Bowersox's 'Give Me One Reason' Dominates 'American Idol' |author=James Montgomery |publisher=MTV |date=March 9, 2010 |access-date=March 25, 2010}}</ref>\n\nAfter [[Siobhan Magnus]]'s elimination from the top 6 of ''[[American Idol]]'', Bowersox became the last remaining female contestant in the competition.\n\nBowersox was the first female contestant to make it to the finale since [[Jordin Sparks]] won the title in 2007. She is also the first contestant in ''American Idol'' history to have one of their original songs played on the show, or at least during their hometown package.<ref>{{cite web|last=Slezak |first=Michael |url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/05/22/american-idol-crystal-bowersox-lee-dewyze/ |title='Idolatry': Breaking down the Crystal-Lee finale (and bidding adieu to Casey) on 'American Idol' |publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=May 22, 2010 |access-date=November 4, 2015}}</ref> Crystal's original song \"Holy Toledo\" was played on the May 19 Top 3 Results show as the background music for her homecoming package - when she returned to Toledo, Ohio and Elliston, Ohio the previous weekend - and segued into her live performance of the same song at \"Bowerstock\".\n\nDuring her time on ''Idol'', Bowersox dated Tony Kusian, but the couple broke up just hours before the ''Idol'' finale.<ref>{{cite news | title = Crystal Bowersox and Boyfriend Split Before Idol Finale | publisher = People | date = May 27, 2010 | url = http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20420919,00.html | access-date = September 25, 2010 | archive-date = September 28, 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100928121354/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20420919,00.html | url-status = dead }}</ref>\n\nOn the final performance day, in [[Simon Cowell]]'s final critique on ''American Idol'', he called her performance of \"[[Up to the Mountain (MLK Song)|Up to the Mountain]]\" \"outstanding\" and \"by far, the best performance and song of the night\".\n\nOn May 26, 2010, Bowersox was named runner-up to winner [[Lee DeWyze]]. She announced that after her ''Idol'' career, she wants to bring more awareness to type 1 diabetes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/idolchatter/post/2010/05/crystal-bowersox-and-lee-dewyze-dish-on-judges-picks-why-viewers-should-vote-for-them/1/ |title=Crystal Bowersox and Lee DeWyze dish on judges' picks, why viewers should vote for them|date=May 20, 2010|work=USA Today|access-date=May 30, 2010}}</ref>\n\nBowersox is the third ''Idol'' Runner-Up (preceded by [[Clay Aiken]] and [[David Archuleta]]) to never be in the Bottom 3 or Bottom 2.\n\n===Performances===\n{|class=\"wikitable\" style=\"text-align: center;\"\n|-\n!Episode\n!Theme\n!Song choice\n!Original recording 15, 2010 }}</ref> Thus, the audience has no way of knowing which of the Top 3 was the second-lowest vote-getter that night after [[Michael Lynche]], who was eliminated.</small>\n* <small>{{note|3|Note 3}} Song selected by [[Ellen DeGeneres]].</small>\n\n==Post-''Idol'' career==\nOn May 27, 2010, one day after Bowersox's second place ''Idol'' finish, it was announced that she had signed with [[19 Entertainment]]/[[Jive Records]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/29/arts/television/29arts-AMERICANIDOL_BRF.html?ref=todayspaper/ |title=''American Idol'' Finalists Sign Record Deals|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 28, 2010 |access-date=May 28, 2010|last1=Itzkoff |first1=Compiled by Dave }}</ref> Her single \"[[Up to the Mountain (MLK Song)|Up to the Mountain]]\" has since been released to radio stations and iTunes.\n\n===2010\u201312: ''Farmer's Daughter''===\nBowersox's debut album, ''[[Farmer's Daughter (album)|Farmer's Daughter]]'', was released to stores and iTunes on December 14, 2010.  Bowersox performed her single \"[[Farmer's Daughter (Crystal Bowersox song)|Farmer's Daughter]]\" on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' on December 16, 2010.\n\nOn October 7, 2011, [[RCA Music Group]] announced it was disbanding [[Jive Records]] along with [[Arista Records]] and [[J Records]]. With the shutdown, all other artists previously signed to these three labels would see their future material released under the [[RCA Records]] brand.<ref>{{cite web|last=Christman |first=Ed |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/industry/record-labels/rca-s-new-executive-team-named-under-ceo-1005324782.story |title=RCA's New Executive Team Named Under CEO Peter Edge Amid Layoffs (Update) |publisher=Billboard.biz |date=August 23, 2011 |access-date=November 1, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fmqb.com/article.asp?id=2268707 |title=Radio Industry News, Music Industry Updates, Arbitron Ratings, Music News and more! |publisher=FMQB |access-date=November 1, 2012 |archive-date=November 8, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111108044953/http://www.fmqb.com/article.asp?id=2268707 |url-status=dead }}</ref> However, Bowersox was not one of the artists who made the move, and was instead left without a record label.\n\nShe made her acting debut on a second-season episode of ''[[Body of Proof]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Slezak |first=Michael |url=http://www.tvline.com/2011/10/crystal-bowersox-body-of-proof-preview-season-2-episode-6/ |title=Crystal Bowersox on Body of Proof Season 2, Episode 6, Second Chances |publisher=TVLine |date=October 25, 2011 |access-date=November 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Stanhope |first=Kate |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Idol-Crystal-Bowersox-Body-Proof-1038986.aspx?rss=breakingnews&partnerid=imdb&profileid=01 |title=Crystal Bowersox Makes Her Acting Debut on Body of Proof: \"I Was Pretty Insecure\" - Today's News: Our Take |publisher=TVGuide.com |date=October 24, 2011 |access-date=November 4, 2015}}</ref>\n\nAn EP of pre-''Idol'' recordings was called ''Once Upon a Time...'' was self-released in June 2012.\n\nShe was a guest on the [[Blues Traveler]] album, ''[[Suzie Cracks the Whip]]'', performing vocals with [[John Popper]] on the song \"I Don't Wanna Go\", and appeared with them in concert at their concert of July 4, 2012 at [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre]] in Colorado.\n\n===2012\u2013present: ''All That for This''===\n\nIn October 2012, Bowersox signed a recording deal with [[Shanachie Records]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/idol-worship/american-idol-crystal-bowersox-signs-376098 |title=American Idol's Crystal Bowersox Signs Label Deal With Shanachie |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |date=October 3, 2012 |access-date=November 1, 2012}}</ref>\n\nOn January 7, 2013, it was confirmed that Bowersox's second studio album, ''[[All That for This]],'' would be released March 26, 2013.<ref name=Bowersox>{{cite news|last=Mansfield|first=Bryan|title=Crystal Bowersox unveils new single|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/idolchatter/2013/02/05/crystal-bowersox-new-single-dead-weight/1894733/|publisher=USA Today|access-date=February 6, 2013|date=February 5, 2013}}</ref> The album was produced by [[Steve Berlin]] of [[Los Lobos]] and features [[Jakob Dylan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mjsbigblog.com/new-crystal-bowersox-album-set-for-march-photo.htm |title=New Crystal Bowersox Album Set for March (PHOTO) |date=January 7, 2013 |publisher=Mjsbigblog.com |access-date=July 12, 2014}}</ref> Bowersox debuted the first single from the album, \"Dead Weight\", on ''[[On Air with Ryan Seacrest (radio)|On Air with Ryan Seacrest]]'' on February 5, 2013. Bowersox told Seacrest, \"This song means more to me than even I can completely comprehend.\"<ref name=Bowersox />\n\nBowersox began a headlining tour in support of the album on March 1, 2013. The band Mont\u00eb Mar was her concert opener, as well as her backing band on dates through March 31, 2013.<ref name=\"Monte Mar Facebook\">{{cite web|title=Monte Mar February 28, 2013 status|url=https://www.facebook.com/montemarmusic|publisher=Facebook|access-date=June 15, 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"Monte Mar Website\">{{cite web|title=Tour Dates|url=http://montemarmusic.com/tour/|publisher=Monte Mar|access-date=June 14, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316052217/http://montemarmusic.com/tour/|archive-date=March 16, 2013}}</ref> On March 25, 2013, Bowersox appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' and performed her song \"Movin' On\" to promote the album. It was announced here that Bowersox will play [[Patsy Cline]] in the Broadway production of ''Always, Patsy Cline.''<ref name=\"Shallow Nation\">{{cite web|title=Crystal Bowersox on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno Video: 'Movin' On' Performance March 25, 2013|url=http://www.shallownation.com/2013/03/26/crystal-bowersox-tonight-show-with-jay-leno-video-movin-on-performance-march-25-2013/|publisher=Shallow Nation|access-date=June 14, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330101811/http://www.shallownation.com/2013/03/26/crystal-bowersox-tonight-show-with-jay-leno-video-movin-on-performance-march-25-2013|archive-date=March 30, 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> It was announced on June 11, 2013 that Bowersox would be headlining the Lancaster Festival in [[Lancaster, Ohio]] on June 27, 2013<ref name=\"The Columbus Dispatch\">{{cite web|title=Bowersox to perform at Lancaster Festival|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/life_and_entertainment/2013/06/11/1aa-showtell11-art-gqpnajjp-1.html|publisher=The Columbus Dispatch|access-date=June 15, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nBowersox and musician Brian Walker were married on October 10, 2010, at Uncommon Ground Caf\u00e9 in Chicago, the restaurant where the couple had met six years earlier while both were performing at Open Mic Night.<ref>{{cite news|last=Laudadio|first=Marisa|title=Crystal Bowersox Gets Married!|work=People|date=October 10, 2010|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20433323,00.html|access-date=October 16, 2010}}</ref> It was announced on May 6, 2013, that they were ending their marriage.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Coughlan|first=Maggie|last2=Laudadio|first2=Marisa|title=Crystal Bowersox Splits From Husband|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20697571,00.html|work=People|access-date=May 7, 2013|date=May 6, 2013}}</ref>\n\nWhile appearing on ''[[Good Day L.A.]]'' to promote her Christmas album on November 26, 2013, Bowersox came out as [[bisexual]]. \"I have been bisexual as long as I can remember,\" she said.  Bowersox then performed her song \"Coming Out For Christmas\" which explores the subject matter.<ref>{{cite web|title=Crystal Bowersox: I Have Been Bisexual For As Long As I Can Remember VIDEO|date=November 28, 2013 |url=http://www.mjsbigblog.com/crystal-bowersox-bisexual-long-can-remember-video.htm|access-date=December 1, 2013}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n\n===Studio albums===\n{|
