This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Monty_Byrom","to":"Monty Byrom"}],"pages":{"23655571":{"pageid":23655571,"ns":0,"title":"Monty Byrom","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musician and song-writer}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Monty Byrom\n| birth_date       = 1958\n| birth_place      = [[Corpus Christi, Texas]], U.S.\n| genre            = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Americana (music)|Americana]], [[Country music|Country]], [[Album oriented rock]]\n| occupations      = songwriter, singer, musician, producer\n| instruments      = guitar, keyboards\n| current_member_of = The Byrom Brothers\n| past_member_of   = [[Billy Satellite]]<br />New Frontier<br />[[Big House (American band)|Big House]]<br />[[The Buckaroos]]<br />Zen Road Pilots<br />Monty Byrom & the Road Pilots\n}}\n\n'''Monty Byrom''' (born 1958) is an American [[rock music|rock]], [[blues music|blues]] and [[country music|country]] guitarist, singer, songwriter and producer.<ref name=\":7\">{{Cite web |title=Monty Byron Credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/monty-byrom-mn0000925418/credits |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref> He fronted the rock band [[Billy Satellite]], co-writing several songs for the band that later became hits for [[Eddie Money]].  Byrom later became more involved in collaborations with Money, writing or co-writing songs on future Money albums and touring with Money on occasion.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web |last=Mu\u00f1oz |first=Matt |date=2012-09-05 |title=Band reunion is magical for Zen Road Pilots {{!}} Bakotopia |url=http://www.bakotopia.com/content/band-reunion-magical-zen-road-pilots |access-date=2022-06-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905050134/http://www.bakotopia.com/content/band-reunion-magical-zen-road-pilots |archive-date=September 5, 2012 }}</ref> Later while leading the \"soul country\" band [[Big House (American band)|Big House]], Byrom made a significant contribution to the new [[Bakersfield Sound]], with a nod to his Bakersfield roots.<ref name=\":8\">{{Cite web |last=Timmons |first=Joseph |date=2019-02-21 |title=Artists Spotlight: Monty Byrom, American Music Legend and his group The Byrom Brothers |url=https://indiepulsemusic.com/2019/02/21/monty-byrom/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=IndiePulse Music Magazine |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n== Early life ==\nByrom was born in\n[[Corpus Christi, Texas|Corpus Christi]], [[Texas]] and raised in [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], [[California]].<ref name=\":8\" /> His original musical influences were [[Merle Haggard]], [[Billy Mize]], [[Buck Owens]], [[Otis Redding]], and [[Bobby Womack]].<ref name=\":9\">{{Cite web |title=Monty Byrom |url=https://wtfrecords.net/music-alive-in-the-new-york-times/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=WTF Records |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nWhen he was seventeen, he joined the [[United States Navy]].<ref name=\":9\" /> After attending the Norfolk Navy School of Music, he played in the Navy band, performing at high schools and colleges across the United States.<ref name=\":9\" />\n\nAlthough Bakersfield had a rising country music scene, he grew to prefer the music of [[Eric Clapton]], [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]], [[Deep Purple]], [[Jimi Hendrix|Jim Hendrix]], and [[Santana (band)|Santana]].<ref name=\":1\">\"[https://heavyharmonies.ipbhost.com/topic/34309-billy-satellite-ii/ Billy Satellite - II]\". ''Heavy Harmonies Forums''. Retrieved 2022-06-24.</ref> After the Navy, he played in a Bay Area band, The Heaters.<ref name=\":1\" /> In the 1980s, he played with the Dead Family.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\n== Career ==\n=== Billy Satellite ===\n{{Main|Billy Satellite}}\nIn the early 1980s, Byrom was a founding member of the [[Alameda, California]] band [[Billy Satellite]].<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web |title=Billy Satellite Songs, Albums, Reviews, Bio & More |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/billy-satellite-mn0001541500 |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref><ref name=\":0\" /> He provided lead vocals and played guitar and keyboards for the [[Album-oriented rock]] band.<ref name=\":2\" /> He also co-wrote the band's songs.<ref name=\":7\" /> The band signed with [[Capitol Records]] by [[John S. Carter]] in 1983.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":9\" /> Their album, ''Billy Satellite'', was produced by [[Don Gehman]] and recorded at [[Rumbo Recorders]] in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name=\":2\" /> The band toured with [[Night Ranger]] and [[Jefferson Starship]] in support of the album, which yielded two minor hits.<ref name=\":1\" /> Although recorded, the band's second album was never released and they were dropped by Capitol. Billy Satellite broke up shortly afterward.<ref name=\":2\" />\n\n=== New Frontier ===\nAfter Billy Satellite, Byrom formed the band [[New Frontier (band)|New Frontier]] which [[Glenn Letsch]] ([[Gamma (band)|Gamma]]) on bass, Marc Nelson on drums, and David Neuhauser on keyboards.<ref name=\":1\" /> The band signed with MIKA Records, an imprint of [[Polydor Records]], and released a self-titled album in 1987.<ref name=\":1\" /> Because all of its members were involved in other bands and projects, this group was short-lived.<ref>{{Cite web |date=December 8, 2019 |title=New Frontier - New Frontier (1988) |url=https://hardrockaorheaven.blogspot.com/2019/12/NEW-FRONTIER-New-Frontier-1988-Billy-Satellite-Richie-Zito-John-Waite.html |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=Hard Rock / AOR Heaven}}</ref>\n\n=== Eddie Money ===\nByrom began writing songs for Eddie Money after the latter had a hit with a cover of \"I Wanna Go Back\" by Billy Satellite (co-written by Byrom).<ref name=\":1\" /> Money's version of \"I Wanna Go Back\" received the ASCAP/BMI Song of the Year Award, based on airplay.<ref name=\":8\" /> He also toured with Money's band for several years.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\nByrom was the producer, engineer, and mixer on Money's 1991 album ''[[Right Here (Eddie Money album)|Right Here]]'', along with providing backing vocals and playing guitar and keyboards.<ref name=\":7\" /> He also co-wrote six of the album's ten tracks, including \"Another Nice Day in L.A.,\" \"Fall In Love Again,\" \"Fire and Water,\" \"Prove It Every Night,\" \"She Takes My Breath Away,\" and \"Things Are Much Better Today.\"<ref>{{Citation |title=Eddie Money - Right Here Album Reviews, Songs & More {{!}} AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/right-here-mw0000265111 |language=en |access-date=2022-06-25}}</ref> He also produced and played guitar on Money's 1992 release ''[[Unplug It In]]''.<ref name=\":7\" />\n\n=== Big House ===\n{{Main|Big House (American band)}}\nFollowing a gathering of musicians in Bakersfield in the mid-1990s, Byrom founded the country music band, [[Big House (American band)|Big House]], with David Neuhauser from New Frontier.<ref name=\":1\" /><ref name=\":8\" /> The duo shared song-writing for the band, and Byrom played guitar and sang lead vocals.<ref name=\":3\">{{Cite web |title=Big House Albums and Discography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/big-house-mn0000760611/discography |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref><ref name=\":7\" /> Byrom's brother, Tanner, was also a member of Big House, playing the drums.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |title=Big House Biography |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/big-house-mn0000760611/biography |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=AllMusic |language=en}}</ref> They signed with [[MCA Nashville]] and released three albums between 1997 and 2000, including ''Big House'', ''Travelin' Kind'', and ''Woodstock Nation''.<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite web |last=Gile |first=Pete |date=2021-06-20 |title=Bakersfield Legend: Monty Byrom |url=https://www.thetroubadourpodcast.com/montybyrom/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=The Troubadour Podcast episode #126 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=\":4\" /> Their fourth album, ''Never Ending Train'', was released in 2008.<ref name=\":3\" /> He produced all four of the band's albums.<ref name=\":7\" /> They were nominated for a [[Academy of Country Music Award]] for top new vocal duet or group in 1998.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Morden |first=Darryl |date=February 25, 1998 |title=Mcgraw Leads With 7 ACM Nominations |url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/1998/feb/25/mcgraw-leads-with-7-acm-nominations/ |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=The Spokesman Review}}</ref><ref name=\":8\" /> They also had four Top 40 Country hits, including \"Cold Outside\" and \"You Ain't Lonely Yet.\"<ref name=\":9\" /><ref name=\":10\">{{Cite web |title=Byrom Brothers |url=https://www.bigbigslo.com/band-blog/2018/11/28/byrom-brothers |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=Big, Big SLO! |language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n=== The Buckaroos ===\n{{Main|The Buckaroos}}\nAfter the death of his friend [[Buck Owens]], Byrom was invited to join Owens' band [[The Buckaroos]] at The Crystal Palace in [[Bakersfield, California]], fronting the band one weekend a month.<ref name=\":5\" /> Byrom played with The Buckaroos for thirteen years, from 2007 to 2019.<ref name=\":6\">{{Cite web |last=Price |first=Robert |date=January 16, 2019 |title=After 13 years, Monty Byrom, Buck Owens' Crystal Palace part ways |url=https://www.bakersfield.com/entertainment/music/after-13-years-monty-byrom-buck-owens-crystal-palace-part-ways/article_ebf0fa24-1900-11e9-b44f-a7273646ba4d.html |access-date=2022-06-25 |website=The Bakersfield Californian |language=en}}</ref> Upon leaving the group, he said, 'Thirteen years and time to move on. I'm going to miss those boys and Jennifer [Keel, backing singer], that's for sure. Finally, in the end, it just came down to...time to move on.\"<ref name=\":6\" /> One of the reasons he quit was because of the increasing success of The Byrom Brothers.<ref name=\":6\" />\n\n=== Zen Road Pilots ===\nIn 2012, Byrom formed the Zen Road Pilots with Tom \"Fee\" Falletti and Ira Walker, former bandmates from Billy Satellite.<ref name=\":0\" /> The band recorded one self-titled album.<ref name=\":0\" />  Changing its name to Monty Byrom and The Road Pilots, this five-piece band played Americana-infused rock and soul in the old-school tradition.<ref name=\":8\" /> They released ''100 Miles South of Eden'' in 2016.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\n=== The Byrom Brothers ===\nThe Road Pilots became The Byrom Brothers, which includes his brother and [[Big House (American band)|Big House]] drummer Tanner Byrom.<ref name=\":6\" /><ref name=\":8\" /> Byrom plays guitar and sings lead vocals.<ref name=\":10\" /> The band also includes studio musician Wil Anderson on bass and keyboardist Chris Neufeld, who was a member of The Road Pilots and also played with Eddie Money.<ref name=\":8\" /><ref name=\":10\" /> Their current release, an album of covers titled ''The Age Of Music'', was released in 2016.<ref name=\"CDBaby\">{{Cite web |title=CD Baby Music Store |url=https://store.cdbaby.com/m/cd/byrombrothers}}</ref>\n\n=== Other ===\nIn 1984, he provided backing vocals for [[Barbra Streisand]] on her album, ''Emotion''.<ref name=\":7\" /> The producer of that track was [[Don Felder]] ([[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]), who mentored Byrom, leading to other projects with major acts.<ref name=\":8\" /> As a result, Byrom wrote songs that were recorded by [[Rita Coolidge]], [[Ace Frehley]], [[Beth Hart]], [[The Knack]], [[Gregg Rolie]], [[David Lee Roth]], [[Stray Cats]], [[George Thorogood]], [[Van Halen]], [[Walela]], and [[Waylon (singer)|Waylon]].<ref name=\":7\" /><ref name=\":8\" />\n\nIn 1992, he played guitar and provided backing vocals for [[Danny Tate]]'s self-named album.<ref name=\":7\" /> He also played guitar on recordings by [[J'Son (singer)|J'Son]], New Frontier, and [[Kathy Troccoli]].<ref name=\":7\" /> In addition, he produced and played instruments on albums for [[Jay Boy Adams]], [[Jared Tyler]], and [[Ted Z & the Wranglers]].<ref name=\":7\" />\n\nHe also worked on numerous movie and film soundtracks, including ''Blackdog'', ''[[The Kids Are Alright (TV series)|The Kids Are Alright]]'', ''Made in America'', ''[[The Slugger's Wife|The Slugger\u2019s Wife]]'', ''[[Secret Admirer (film)|Secret Admirer]]'', and ''[[Sunset Beach (TV series)|Sunset Beat]]''.<ref name=\":8\" /><ref name=\":7\" />\n\n== Awards and honors ==\n\n* Byrom won The Guitar Wars in northern California.<ref name=\":8\" />\n* \"I Wanna Go Back,\" a song he co-wrote, won the ASCAP/BMI Song of the Year Award.<ref name=\":8\" />\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n{{Authority control}}\n\n{{DEFAULTSORT:Byrom, Monty}}\n[[Category:1958
