{{URL|kennyloggins.com}}\n}}\n'''Kenneth Clark Loggins''' (born January 7, 1948)<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2019/01/07/UPI-Almanac-for-Monday-Jan-7-2019/6991546835238/?ur3=1|title= UPI Almanac for Monday, Jan, 7, 2019|work= [[United Press International]]|date=January 7, 2019|access-date=September 21, 2019|archive-date= September 21, 2019|archive-url= https://archive.today/20190921143309/https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2019/01/07/UPI-Almanac-for-Monday-Jan-7-2019/6991546835238/?ur3=1|url-status=live|quote= singer Kenny Loggins in 1948 (age 71)}}</ref> is an American singer, guitarist and songwriter.<ref name=\"Huffpo King of Soundtrack\" /> His early songs were recorded with the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]] in 1970,<ref name=\"Billboard Bio\" /> which led to seven albums recorded with [[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]] as [[Loggins and Messina]] from 1972 to 1977.<ref name=\"Loggins & Messina: Discography\" /> His early soundtrack contributions date back to ''[[A Star Is Born (1976 film)|A Star Is Born]]'' in 1976,<ref name=\"Kenny Loggins: Filmography\" /> and he is known as [[Honorific nicknames in popular music#L|the King of the Movie Soundtrack]].<ref name=\"Huffpo King of Soundtrack\" /><ref name=\"Download.com King\" /> As a solo artist, Loggins experienced a string of soundtrack successes, including an [[Academy Award]] nomination for \"[[Footloose (song)|Footloose]]\" in 1985.<ref name=\"Kenny Loggins: Awards\" /> ''Finally Home'' was released in 2013, shortly after Loggins formed the group [[Blue Sky Riders]] with [[Gary Burr]] and [[Georgia Middleman]].<ref name=\"Huffpo Finally Home\" /> He won a [[Emmy Award|Daytime Emmy Award]], two [[Grammy Awards]] and was nominated for an [[Academy Award]], a [[Tony Award]] and a [[Golden Globe Award]].\n\n== Early life ==\nLoggins was born in [[Everett, Washington]], the youngest of three brothers. His father, Robert George Loggins, was a salesman of [[English Americans|English]] and [[Irish Americans|Irish]] ancestry,<ref>{{cite web| url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:K934-J26| title=Kenny Loggins' parents on the 1940 US Census| website=[[FamilySearch]]}}</ref> while his mother, Lina (n\u00e9e Massie), was a homemaker of [[Italian Americans|Italian]] descent, from [[Avezzano]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.facebook.com/KennyLoggins/photos/a.10150344195468830/10153083669338830/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/58759123829/10153083669338830 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited| title=Something happens to your heart when you look into those little eyes...| publisher=Facebook| first=Kenny| last=Loggins| date=March 7, 2015| quote=This is family. 'La Familia,' as my Italian mama used to say.}}{{cbignore}}</ref> They lived in [[Detroit]] and [[Seattle]] before settling in [[Alhambra, California]]. Loggins attended [[San Gabriel Mission High School]], graduating in 1966. He formed a band, The Second Helping, that released three singles during 1968 and 1969 on [[Viva Records (U.S.)|Viva Records]]. [[Greg Shaw]] described the efforts as \"excellent [[punk rock|punky]] [[folk music|folk-pop]] records\" that were written by Loggins who was likely to be the bandleader and singer as well; Shaw included \"Let Me In\" on both ''[[Highs in the Mid-Sixties, Volume 2]]'' and the ''[[Pebbles, Volume 9 (CD)|Pebbles, Volume 9]]'' CD.<ref>Liner notes, Highs in the Mid-Sixties, Volume 2. Ref. August 21, 2008.</ref>\n\nLoggins had a short gig playing guitar for [[The Electric Prunes#The \"New Improved\" Electric Prunes|the New Improved Electric Prunes]] in 1969 before writing four songs for the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]] that were included on their album ''[[Uncle Charlie & His Dog Teddy]]''.<ref name=POEM>[http://www.poemhunter.com/lyrics/kenny-loggins/biography/ \"Biography: Kenny Loggins\"] Poem Hunter.com</ref> During his early 20s, he was in the band Gator Creek with [[Mike Deasy]]. The first recorded version of \"[[Danny's Song]]\" (later recorded by Loggins and Messina and a No. 7 Hot 100 hit for [[Anne Murray]] in 1973) was included on their only album, released on [[Mercury Records]].\n\n== Loggins and Messina ==\n[[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]], formerly of [[Poco (band)|Poco]] and [[Buffalo Springfield]], was working as an independent record producer for [[Columbia Records]] in 1970 when he was introduced to Loggins, then a little-known singer-songwriter who was signed to [[ABC Records|ABC-Dunhill]].\n\nThe two recorded a number of Loggins's compositions in Messina's home living room. When Columbia signed Loggins (with Messina's help) to a six-album contract, recording began in earnest for Loggins's debut album, with Messina as producer. He assembled The Kenny Loggins Band by summoning his old friends bassist Larry Sims and drummer Merel Bregante (both formerly of [[the Sunshine Company]], a disbanded 1960s group from Los Angeles), violinist/multireedist Al Garth and multireedist Jon Clarke. Keyboardist [[Michael Omartian]] also played on the album and despite dropping out at the start of the touring, continued to play keyboards on the next two albums. Los Angeles\u2013based session percussionist [[Milt Holland]], described by Messina as an [[ethnomusicology|ethnomusicologist]], also contributed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Flans |first=Robyn |url=http://www.mixonline.com/news/profiles/classic-tracks-loggins-messinas-vahevala/375146 |title=Classic Tracks: Loggins & Messina's \"Vahevala\" |publisher=Mixonline |date=January 9, 2004 |access-date=November 1, 2015}}</ref>\n\nMessina originally intended to lend his name to the Loggins project only to help introduce the unknown Loggins to Messina's well-established Buffalo Springfield and Poco audiences. But by the time the album was completed, Messina had contributed so much to the album in terms of songwriting, arrangement, instrumentation and vocals that an \"accidental\" duo was born. Thus the full name of their first album was ''[[Sittin' In (Loggins and Messina album)|Kenny Loggins with Jim Messina Sittin' In]]''. The album's first single release, the Caribbean-flavored \"Vahevala\", found top 3 success on [[WCFL (AM)|WCFL]] on May 18, 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oldiesloon.com/ilc/wcfl051872.htm|title=WCFL \u2013 all hit music in the Midwest|date=May 18, 1972|access-date=January 5, 2013}}</ref>\n\n[[File:Kenny Loggins.jpg|thumb|A publicity photo, {{circa|1980}}]]\nAlthough the album went unnoticed by radio upon release, it eventually found success by fall 1972, particularly on college campuses where the pair toured heavily. Loggins and Messina's vocal harmonies meshed so well that what was begun as a one-off album became an entity in itself. Audiences regarded the pair as a genuine duo rather than as a solo act with a well-known producer. Instead of continuing to produce Loggins as a sole performer, they decided to record as a duo, Loggins & Messina.\n\n''\"When our first album, 'Sittin' In', came out, we started receiving a lot of excitement about the music and good sales\"'', Messina recalled in 2005.\n{{Blockquote|text=We had a choice. It was either I now go on and continue to produce him and we do the solo career or we stay together and let this work. For me, I did not desire to go back out on the road. I had had enough of that and I wanted to produce records. But [[Clive Davis]] (then president of the record company) intervened and said, \"You know, I think you'd be making a mistake if you guys didn't take this opportunity. Things like this only happen once in a lifetime. It may merit you sleeping on it overnight and making a decision that will be in your best interest.\" He was absolutely correct. Kenny made the decision as well. It delayed his solo career, but it gave him an opportunity, I think, to have one.<ref name=\"Thibodeaux\">\"Together again: Kenny Loggins and [[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]] bring their hits to Biloxi\", by Ron Thibodeaux, The Times-Picayune (New Orleans), July 29, 2005.</ref> }}\n\nBoth members of the duo were guitarists: Loggins played rhythm guitar with both acoustic and electric guitar and harmonica and Messina played lead guitar with both acoustic and electric guitar, mandolin and Dobro. Over the next four years they produced five more albums of original material in the studio, plus one album of [[Cover version|covers]] of other artists' material and two live albums. They sold 16 million records and were the most successful duo of the early 1970s, surpassed later in the decade only by [[Daryl Hall & John Oates]].<ref name=\"Thibodeaux\" /> Their work also included [[Lynn Anderson]]'s \"[[Listen to a Country Song (song)|Listen to a Country Song]]\", which was released in 1972 and reached No.&nbsp;4 on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Singles]] chart, and \"[[Danny's Song]]\" and \"[[A Love Song (Loggins and Messina song)|A Love Song]]\" for [[Anne Murray]], which reached No.&nbsp;7 and No.&nbsp;12 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot 100]] pop chart in 1973 and 1974 respectively.  The latter two songs also hit No.&nbsp;1 on the Canadian ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' Top Singles chart. Later studio albums often found Loggins and Messina more as two solo artists sharing the same record than as a genuine partnership. As they both noted in 2005, their collaboration eventually became more a competition. Following their January 1976 release of ''[[Native Sons (Loggins and Messina album)|Native Sons]]'' and a final concert in [[Honolulu]], Hawaii, on September 25, 1976, the pair amicably and quietly parted to pursue solo careers. A greatest-hits album, ''[[The Best of Friends (album)|The Best of Friends]]'', was released in November 1976. Two months later, a live album, ''[[Finale (album)|Finale]]'' was released, more by record company decision than one intended by the artists, one year after the duo had come to an end.{{citation needed|date=March 2024}}\n\n== Solo career ==\n[[File:Kenny Loggins 1977.jpg|thumb|Loggins performing in 1977]]\nIn 1977, Loggins produced his first solo album, ''[[Celebrate Me Home]]'', which included the successful song \"[[I Believe in Love (Kenny Loggins song)|I Believe in Love]]\", originally sung by [[Barbra Streisand]] in ''[[A Star Is Born (1976 film)|A Star Is Born]]''. ''[[Nightwatch (album)|Nightwatch]]'', a popular album released in 1978, included the hit song \"Whenever I Call You Friend\", a duet with [[Stevie Nicks]] of [[Fleetwood Mac]], co-written with [[Melissa Manchester]]. Loggins followed that in 1979 with ''[[Keep the Fire]]'' and in 1982 with ''[[High Adventure]]''. The latter contained his rock duet with [[Journey (band)|Journey]] frontman [[Steve Perry (musician)|Steve Perry]], \"[[Don't Fight It (Kenny Loggins & Steve Perry song)|Don't Fight It]]\", which rose to No.&nbsp;17 on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot 100]] chart. Loggins abandoned the harmonica in his solo career but continued to play guitar, just as he had done with Loggins & Messina.\n\n=== With Michael McDonald ===\n{{BLP sources section|date=June 2023}}\nLoggins also co-wrote the song \"[[What a Fool Believes]]\" with [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]]. Each recorded his own version of it, with McDonald recording as a member of [[the Doobie Brothers]]. Loggins' version was released first, but the Doobie Brothers' version achieved greater success, reaching No.&nbsp;1 on the Hot 100 and earning Loggins and McDonald the 1980 [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] for [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]].\n\nIn 1979, Loggins and McDonald wrote \"[[This Is It (Kenny Loggins song)|This Is It]]\". The song was a love song and ultimatum to a woman having an affair and stringing her lover along, while refusing to make a final decision.  The song earned Loggins the [[Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance]]. [[NBC]] used the song as theme music for its coverage of the [[NCAA men's basketball tournament]] in 1980 and 1981.\n\n=== Soundtracks ===\nDuring the next decade, Loggins recorded so many successful songs for film soundtracks that he became known as the King of the Movie Soundtrack.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/kenny-loggins \"Kenny Loggins\"] Gale Music Profiles</ref><ref>Franko, Vanessa: [http://www.pe.com/localnews/temecula/stories/PE_News_Local_D_loggins04.326bf83.html \"Temecula film fest to honor Kenny Loggins\"] ''Temecula Press-Enterprise'', August 3, 2010</ref> It began with \"[[I'm Alright (Kenny Loggins song)|I'm Alright]]\" from ''[[Caddyshack]]''. Hits followed with \"[[Footloose (song)|Footloose]]\" (his only solo No.&nbsp;1) and \"[[I'm Free (Heaven Helps the Man)]]\" from ''[[Footloose (1984 soundtrack)|Footloose]]''; \"[[Meet Me Half Way]]\" from ''[[Over the Top (1987 film)|Over the Top]]''; and \"[[Danger Zone (song)|Danger Zone]]\" and \"[[Playing with the Boys]]\" from ''[[Top Gun]]''. Loggins also performed [[Nobody's Fool (Kenny Loggins song)|\"Nobody's Fool\"]] for the film ''[[Caddyshack II]]''. He performed as a member of [[USA for Africa]] on the famine-relief fundraising single \"[[We Are the World]]\", which led to an appearance performing \"Footloose\" at the Philadelphia leg of the July 13, 1985, [[Live Aid]] famine-relief dual-venue charity concert and global television broadcast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://liveaid.free.fr/ |title=The definitive LIVE AID site : all you wanted to know about the greatest concert on Earth |publisher=Liveaid.free.fr |access-date=June 25, 2014}}</ref>\n\nDuring the 1990s, Loggins continued his album career, including the popular 1994 children's album ''[[Return to Pooh Corner]]'', which included the title single, a reworking of \"[[House at Pooh Corner (song)|House at Pooh Corner]]\", written for his newborn son Luke.\n\nIn 1991, Loggins recorded and produced ''[[Leap of Faith (Kenny Loggins album)|Leap of Faith]]'', which included the single \"[[Conviction of the Heart]]\". Vice President [[Al Gore]] called this song \"the unofficial anthem of the [[environmental movement]]\". On [[Earth Day]] 1995, Loggins performed at [[The National Mall]] in Washington, D.C., before a live audience of 500,000.\n\nIn 1997, Loggins released the album ''[[The Unimaginable Life]]'', based on a book he co-wrote with his then-wife Julia. Tracks include \"Now That I Know Love\", \"The Art of Letting Go\" and \"One Chance at a Time\". The album was produced by Loggins and [[Randy Jackson]] with background vocals by [[Skyler Jett]], Lamont VanHook and Howard Smith.\n\nIn 1998, Loggins recorded a version of the ''[[Sesame Street]]'' song \"One Small Voice\" for the ABC television special ''[[Elmopalooza]]'', which was included as a track on the Grammy Award-winning [[Elmopalooza! (soundtrack)|soundtrack album]].\n\n=== Other work ===\n[[File:Kenny Loggins-and Boston Pops 2.jpg|thumb|right|Loggins with [[Boston Pops Orchestra]] and conductor [[Keith Lockhart]], June 22, 2011]]\nLoggins scored a No. 1 single on the ''Billboard'' [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|adult contemporary chart]] in 1997 with \"For the First Time\" (his [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-nominated song from ''One Fine Day''). In 2000, he performed the theme song for Disney's ''[[The Tigger Movie]]'', \"[[Your Heart Will Lead You Home]]\", which he co-wrote with [[Richard and Robert Sherman]].\n\nIn 1999, he appeared as himself on the television show ''[[Dharma & Greg]]'' in the episode \"[[List of Dharma & Greg episodes#Season 3: 1999\u20132000|Tye-Dying the Knot]]\", performing at Abby and Larry's wedding.\nIn 2004, Loggins appeared as himself in episode three, \"Well Well Well,\" of Fox TV's ''[[Method & Red]]''. In 2005, Loggins and Messina gave a nationwide tour that resulted in the CD and DVD ''Loggins and Messina Sittin' In Again''. The tour's concerts were three hours long with an intermission and included an acoustic set in the middle. Complete with a set change that turned the stage into an old gas station setting, the show had a large IMAG video screen that showed old footage of the band, as well as tribute footage of recently deceased former L&M bandmate Jon Clarke. In 2007, Loggins joined the new recording company 180 Music for the release of his album ''[[How About Now]]''. That year he was also inducted into Hollywood's Sunset Boulevard RockWalk.{{citation needed|date=February 2021}}\n\nIn 2009, he recorded a new children's album, ''[[All Join In]]'', but it was not released due to complications with his record company. In 2009 Loggins and Messina toured the United States and Canada, reviving their \"Sittin' In Again tour\". In 2011, he performed a short tour in South East Asia including Manila, Philippines and Singapore. On June 3, 2011, he performed at the Arcada Theater in St. Charles, Illinois. He stopped by the Eddie and Jobo Show in Chicago to talk about his music, his personal life and what kind of show you can expect from him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://khitschicago.radio.com/2011/06/02/hell-be-in-st-charles-tomorrow-but-today-kenny-loggins-is-with-eddie-jobo/ |title=Kenny Loggins Chats With Eddie & Jobo |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819104421/http://khitschicago.radio.com/2011/06/02/hell-be-in-st-charles-tomorrow-but-today-kenny-loggins-is-with-eddie-jobo/ |archive-date=August 19, 2011 }}</ref>\n\nThe 2016 parody film ''[[Donald Trump's The Art of the Deal: The Movie]]'' features an original song by Loggins, ''The Art of the Deal'', written specifically for the film. In July 2016 Loggins performed on ABC's ''[[Greatest Hits (TV series)|Greatest Hits]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abc.com/shows/greatest-hits/|title=Watch Greatest Hits TV Show - ABC.com|website=ABC|access-date=November 18, 2019|archive-date=March 29, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190329090006/https://abc.go.com/shows/greatest-hits/|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2017 Loggins was featured with McDonald on [[Thundercat (musician)|Thundercat's]] single \"Show You the Way\".<ref>Okoth-Obo, Vanessa (January 25, 2017).  [https://pitchfork.com/reviews/tracks/18710-thundercat-show-you-the-way-ft-michael-mcdonald-kenny-loggins/ \"'Show You the Way' (ft. Michael McDonald & Kenny Loggins).\"]  ''Pitchfork.com''.  Retrieved September 17, 2018.</ref> Loggins made a cameo appearance as himself in episode 1 of season 3 of the television show ''[[Grace and Frankie]]''.\nIn October 2018, he received the inaugural [[List of San Diego International Film Festival award winners#SDiFF2018 2|Music Icon Award]] at the [[San Diego International Film Festival]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbcsandiego.com/blogs/sounddiego/Kenny-Loggins-SDIFF-San-Diego-International-Film-Festival-Top-Gun-Tom-Cruise-Footloose-Caddyshack-Michael-McDonald-Pendry-San-Diego-497282161.html|title=SDIFF Braves 'Danger Zone' for Kenny Loggins|last=Lothspeich|first=Dustin|website=NBC 7 San Diego|date=October 12, 2018 |language=en|access-date=September 18, 2019}}</ref>\n\nOn September 22 and 24, 2022, Loggins and Messina reunited at the [[Hollywood Bowl]] for a 50-year anniversary weekend celebration of when they played the Bowl supporting their debut album,\u00a0''Sittin'\u00a0In''. The opening set featured songs like \"Danny's Song\" and \"House at Pooh Corner\". Loggins took the second act on his own, performing some of his best-known hits such as \"I'm Alright\", \"Footloose\", and \"Danger Zone\".{{Citation needed|date=September 2022}}\n\n=== Blue Sky Riders ===\nLoggins is a member of Blue Sky Riders, a [[country music]] trio also featuring [[Gary Burr]] and [[Georgia Middleman]].<ref name=\"Huffpo Finally Home\">{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/16/kenny-loggins-blue-sky-riders_n_1273255.html | title = Kenny Loggins' Third Act: Blue Sky Riders | work=Huffington Post | date = February 16, 2012 }}</ref> They released their debut album, ''Finally Home'', on January 29, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Emling|first=Shelley|title=Blue Sky Riders: Kenny Loggins' Trio Celebrates Release Of New Album, 'Finally Home'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/29/blue-sky-riders-kenny-loggins-first-album-finally-home_n_2568564.html|access-date=January 30, 2013|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=January 29, 2013}}</ref> The band released a special pre-release edition of their second studio album, ''Why Not'', in 2015 to Kickstarter backers.<ref>{{cite web|title=PRESS RELEASE 8.2015|url=http://blueskyridersband.com/archives/4423|website=Blue Sky Riders|access-date=January 21, 2018}}</ref>\n\n== Other media ==\n[[File:Kenny Loggins 1995.jpg|thumb|Loggins in 1995]]\nLoggins appears in the 2013 video game ''[[Grand Theft Auto V]]'' playing himself as the host of an in-game radio station called [[Los Santos Rock Radio]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/entertainment/kenny_loggins_to_host_a_radio_station_in_gta_v.html |title=Kenny Loggins To Host a Radio Station in GTA V &#124; Music News @ |publisher=Ultimate-guitar.com |date=August 30, 2013 |access-date=June 25, 2014}}</ref> He also lends the songs \"[[Danger Zone (song)|Danger Zone]]\" and \"[[I'm Free (Heaven Helps the Man)]]\" and sings station jingles.\n\nIn 2014, Loggins appeared as himself in the episode \"Baby Shower\" of the [[Archer season 5|fifth season]] of the animated comedy series ''[[Archer (2009 TV series)|Archer]]''. His song \"[[Danger Zone (song)|Danger Zone]]\" had been a recurring joke in the show. At the end of the episode and during the credits, Loggins also performs a [[Country music|country]] version of \"Danger Zone\" as a duet with the character of [[Cheryl Tunt|Cherlene]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.seattlepi.com/entertainment/tv/tvguide/article/Kenny-Loggins-Brings-Archer-Into-the-Danger-Zone-5284999.php |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140303231625/http://www.seattlepi.com/entertainment/tv/tvguide/article/Kenny-Loggins-Brings-Archer-Into-the-Danger-Zone-5284999.php |url-status= dead |archive-date= March 3, 2014 |title= Kenny Loggins Brings Archer into the \"Danger Zone\" |last= Raftery |first= Liz |date= March 2, 2014 |newspaper= [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |access-date= March 4, 2014}}</ref> Loggins stated in a later interview that his in-show nickname 'K-Log' is a complete creation of the show, stating, \"It was always a joke. That's why it works, because it's so absurd.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spinoff.comicbookresources.com/2014/03/03/kenny-loggins-enters-the-danger-zone-on-archer/ |title=Kenny Loggins Enters the Danger Zone on 'Archer'|date=March 3, 2014}}</ref>\n\nIn 2018, Loggins lent his voice to a caricature of himself on the animated comedy series ''[[Family Guy]]'', in the episode titled \"Veteran Guy\". He also voiced himself in 2019 in \"Yacht Rocky\" from [[Family Guy season 18|season 18]] and in 2021 in the episode \"80's Guy\" from [[Family Guy season 20|season 20]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.noise11.com/news/peter-griffin-just-found-out-bob-welch-is-dead-20191001|title=Peter Griffin Just Found Out Bob Welch is Dead|website=noise11.com|date=October 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://seat42f.com/family-guy-season-20-episode-4-photos-80s-guy/|title=FAMILY GUY Season 20 Episode 4 Photos 80's Guy &#124; Seat42F|date=October 17, 2021}}</ref>\n\nIn 2022, the [[Mall of America]] overlayed their [[Log Chute]] attraction into the \"Kenny Loggins Chute\" for [[April Fools Day]], with the animatronic [[Paul Bunyan]] being redressed as Loggins.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kare11.com/article/entertainment/mall-of-america-kenny-loggins-chute-april-fools-day/89-35cc4a75-3867-490c-b170-4ccf2d5a3bdf |title=A new look for Mall of America's Log Chute? Or just a little fun on April 1st?|publisher=KARE 11|date=April 1, 2022}}\n</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\nLoggins was married to Eva Ein from 1978 to 1990; they had three children: Crosby, Cody and Isabella. In 2007, the oldest, [[Crosby Loggins]], produced his first CD, ''We All Go Home''. In 2008 Crosby Loggins was voted the winner of the [[MTV]] reality show ''[[Rock the Cradle]]''. Cody was born in 1983 and Isabella in 1988.<ref name=SB>{{cite web |last= Dickson |first= John |title= Familiar Faces: Kenny Loggins |url= http://www.santabarbara.com/community/familiar_faces/kenny_loggins/ |archive-url= https://archive.today/20130201233417/http://www.santabarbara.com/community/familiar_faces/kenny_loggins/ |url-status= dead |archive-date= February 1, 2013 |publisher= Santa Barbara-dot-com |access-date= June 25, 2013 }}</ref> As of 2009, Isabella was a music major in college.<ref name=SUN>Brown, Joe: [http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/mar/12/heart-hand-loggins-rides-danger-zone/ \"Heart in hand, Kenny Loggins rides into danger zone\"]. ''[[Las Vegas Sun]]'', March 12, 2009.</ref>\n\nWhen Loggins experienced health problems in 1982, he was referred to Julia Cooper, a colon therapist. Their relationship was limited to a friendship, but near the end of the 1980s, Loggins separated from his wife at nearly the same time Cooper left her husband.<ref name=RECIPE>{{ cite journal | last = Gerber | first = Suzanne | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0820/is_n252/ai_21052115/ | archive-url = http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20111022194152/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0820/is_n252/ai_21052115/ | archive-date = September 20, 2004 | title = Kenny & Julia Loggins' recipe for lasting love | journal = [[Vegetarian Times]] | date = August 1998 }}<!-- Archivedate parameter is a guess --></ref> Loggins's divorce was made final in 1990 and he and Cooper married in July 1992.<ref>Johnson, Robert: [http://blog.mysanantonio.com/weekender/2010/08/music-notes-dont-sell-kenny-loggins-short/ \"Music notes: Don't sell Kenny Loggins short\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722160554/http://blog.mysanantonio.com/weekender/2010/08/music-notes-dont-sell-kenny-loggins-short/ |date=July 22, 2011 }} San Antonio.com, August 27, 2010</ref><ref name=\"note\">{{cite news|first=Betty |last=Hatch |date=September 21, 2007 |url=http://www.selfesteem.org/menu/projects/sbcse/speakers/julialoggins.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015191206/http://www.selfesteem.org/menu/projects/sbcse/speakers/julialoggins.htm |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 15, 2007 |work=Self Esteem |title=Santa Barbara Council for Self-Esteem: Julia Loggins |access-date=March 16, 2009 }}</ref> In 1994 they became involved with [[Equinox (MLM)|Equinox International]], a [[multi-level marketing]] organization and created a promotional video for the company, as did [[Ted Danson]] and [[Dave Parker]].<ref name=EQUINOX>Mills, Ami Chen: [http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/10.03.96/cover/multilevel-9640.html \"Multi-Level Marketing\"] Metroactive News & Issues, October 3, 1996.</ref>\n\nThe couple had two children: Lukas, born in 1993 and Hana, born in 1997.<ref name=note /> After several years of marriage, they assembled material from the journals each kept, which included poems, songs and letters. They authored a 1997 book, ''The Unimaginable Life'', about their relationship. Its purpose was to offer an alternative to typical relationships where spouses feel they cannot be completely honest.<ref name=RECIPE /> Later on, they faced possible bankruptcy.<ref Name=\"note\" />\n\nThe couple divorced in 2004. Loggins said in 2009, \"I got pretty blindsided by Julia's decision to leave. She's a very impulsive woman and she found herself going through a midlife crisis and she didn't know what to make of it and it changed her life.\"<ref name=SUN />\n\nLoggins has a home in the hills north of [[Santa Barbara, California]], and has lived there for several decades.<ref name=SB /> Loggins is a second cousin to singer-songwriter [[Dave Loggins]].<ref>{{cite web |title= iTunes biography: Dave Loggins |url= https://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/dave-loggins/id198984 |publisher= iTunes |access-date= June 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Dave Loggins \u2013 Kenny's Talented Cousin |url= http://geezermusicclub.wordpress.com/2009/07/22/dave-loggins-kennys-talented-cousin/ |publisher= Geezer Music Club |access-date= June 25, 2013|date= July 22, 2009 }}</ref>\n\n== This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Tom_Hambridge","to":"Tom Hambridge"}],"pages":{"33058717":{"pageid":33058717,"ns":0,"title":"Tom Hambridge","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American drummer}}\n\n{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2024}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = Tom Hambridge\n| image             = Tom Hambridge Bio.jpg\n| caption        =\n| image_size        =\n| birth_name      = Thomas Jay Hambridge\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1960|12|20}}\n| birth_place     = [[Buffalo, New York]], United States\n| instruments      = Drums, vocals\n| genre           = Rock, [[Country music|country]], [[blues]]\n| occupations      = Record producer, musician, songwriter, singer\n| label           = Artemis Records, Superstar Records, [[EMI Music Publishing]], Black Rose, Ocean Records, UTR Music Group\n| website            = [http://hambridgetunes.com// Official Website]\n}}\n\n'''Thomas Jay Hambridge'''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ascap.com/ace/search.cfm?requesttimeout=300&mode=results&searchstr=1528370&search_in=c&search_type=exact&search_det=t,s,w,p,b,v&results_pp=10&start=1 |title=American Society of Composers |work=ascap.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> (born December 20, 1960)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://zildjian.com/Artists/H/Tom-Hambridge |title=Artist Website \u2013 Bio |work=zildjian.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> is an American rock, [[Country music|country]], and [[blues]], producer, songwriter, musician and vocalist. Hambridge has received two [[Grammy Awards]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.grammy.com/news/and-the-grammy-went-to-buddy-guy  |title=Grammy Website \u2013 Living Proof |publisher=National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> an ASCAP award,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ascap.com/eventsawards/awards/ascapcma/2007/winners.html |title=ASCAP Awards 2007 |work=ascap.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> seven Grammy nominations,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nashvillemusicguide.net/october-2010-producers-spotlight-tom-hambridge/ |title=Nashville Music Guide \u22122010 Producers Spotlight, Tom Hambridge |work=nashvillemusicguide.net |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> seven Boston Music Awards, and has been inducted into the Buffalo Hall of Fame.<ref name=\"buffalo\">{{cite web | url=http://www.buffalomusic.org/2001_thambridge.html  |title=Buffalo Hall of Fame Inductees \u2013 2001 |work=buffalomusic.org |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In December 2015, Hambridge was given the key to his hometown of [[Buffalo, New York]] with Mayor [[Byron Brown]] declaring December 28 \"Tom Hambridge Day.\"<ref>{{cite web | url= http://buffalonews.com/2015/12/28/music-talent-tom-hambridge-has-his-own-day-in-buffalo/ |title= Tom Hambridge Day|work=buffalonews.com |year=2015 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> Hambridge's songs have been recorded by several notable artists and have been featured in movie productions, commercials and television programs. He has been referred to as \"The White [[Willie Dixon]]\" by Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Inductee [[Buddy Guy]]<ref>{{cite web | url= http://zildjian.com/Artists/H/Tom-Hambridge|title= White Willie Dixon |work=zildjian.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> and [[Susan Tedeschi]]'s \"Secret Weapon\".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.moderndrummer.com/updatefull/200001290/Tom%20Hambridge|title= Susan Tedeschi's Secret Weapon |website=Moderndrummer.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\nBorn and raised in [[Buffalo, New York]], Hambridge began learning the drums at the age of 5. He played his first paying gig, a bar mitzvah, in third grade. Throughout his school years, Hambridge played in garage bands, his high school orchestra and jazz band. After graduating from high school in 1979, he received a scholarship at Boston's Berklee College of Music.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.berklee.edu/bt/131/alum_profile.html |title=Alum Profile: Tom Hambridge 83-Renaissance Man in a City of Specialists &#124; Berklee College of Music|first= Mark|last=Small|work=berklee.edu |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n[[File:Tom Hambridge Drums.jpg|thumb|left |alt= Tom Playing Drums.| Tom Hambridge]]\n \nHe received his degree in Professional Music in 1983. After graduation, he worked for three years as drummer and lead singer for the blues guitarist [[Roy Buchanan]]. While working with Buchanan, Hambridge contributed as a musician on Buchanan's release, ''Live: Amazing Grace''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/live-amazing-grace-r1626349/credits |title=Roy Buchanan \u2013 Live Amazing Grace |first= Roy|last=Buchanan |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In the meantime, he formed the band \"T.H. and the Wreckage\". In 1988, the band released ''Born to Rock,''<ref name=\"blackrose\">{{cite web | url=http://www.blackroserecords.net/store.html|title= Black Rose Records |work=blackroserecords.net |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> one of several independent, self-produced albums Hambridge has completed. ''Born To Rock'' was the first of the many [[Boston Music Awards]] he has received. In the meantime, he assisted promoters assemble backup bands for artists such as [[Bo Diddley]], [[Percy Sledge]], [[Chuck Berry]], [[Gary Puckett]], and [[Sha Na Na]].<ref name=\"buffalo\"/>\n\nHambridge released his own album ''Still Running'' in 1996.<ref name=\"stillrunning\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/still-running-r289975|title= Still Running, Hambridge |last= Tom Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn 1997, he produced [[Susan Tedeschi]]'s ''[[Just Won't Burn]]''. Hambridge wrote Tedeschi's Top 10 hits \"Rock Me Right\" and \"It Hurt So Bad\".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.eminashville.com/bios/thambridge.html |title=EMI Nashville \u2013 Tom Hambridge |work=eminashville.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In the meantime, he also released his own album ''Balderdash'' in 2000.<ref name=\"balderdash\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/balderdash-r503030|title= Balderdash, Hambridge |last= Tom Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Hambridge received a subsequent 2004 Grammy nomination ([[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Blues Album]]) for his contributions on [[Johnny Winter]]'s release ''I'm A Bluesman''  (\"Cheatin' Blues\" and \"Lone Wolf\").<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/store/artist/album/0,,2890478,00.html |title= Artist Direct \u2013 Johnny Winter -I'm A Bluesman |work=artistdirect.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Shortly thereafter, Hambridge released his album ''Bang N' Roll'' (2004) and the album ''Live'' (2007).<ref name=\"bangnroll\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bang-n-roll-r705780|title= Bang N' Roll, Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nIn 2008, he received Grammy nominations ([[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album]]) for his work on [[Buddy Guy]]'s ''[[Skin Deep (Buddy Guy album)|Skin Deep]]''. ''Skin Deep'' debuted at number 68 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] which was the highest position of any of Guy's previous albums, and was number 1 on the Billboard Blues Album Chart. Hambridge released his own album ''Boogieman'' (2009).<ref name=\"boogieman\">{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/boogieman-r1553953|title= Boogieman, Hambridge |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In 2011, he won the [[Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Blues Album]] for co-writing and producing [[Buddy Guy]]'s album ''[[Living Proof (Buddy Guy album)|Living Proof]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2010-10-31-buddy-guy_N.htm |title= USA Today \u2013 Buddy Guy, Living Proof |first=Steve |last=Jones |work=Artistdirect.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nHe was credited as the producer, songwriter and percussionist for [[George Thorogood and the Destroyers]] 2011 release ''[[2120 South Michigan Ave.]]'', which included the song \"Going Back\" that reached number 1 on Classic Rock Radio. Also in 2011, he wrote and produced [[B. B. King]] and [[Buddy Guy]]'s duet \"Stay Around A Little Longer.\"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.grammy.com/news/and-the-grammy-went-to-buddy-guy |title= Grammy \u2013 Buddy Guy, Stay Around A Little Longer |publisher=National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref>\n\nOther recognized 2011 successes include writing/co-writing all songs on [[Quinn Sullivan (musician)|Quinn Sullivan]]'s release ''Cyclone''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/cyclone-r2141383&sa=U&ei=eoJvTqq4AvSKsALZtLjCCQ&ved=0CBgQFjABOAo&usg=AFQjCNEm_JWDfRJwNJvB369YVbpAFE9pQw |title=Quinn Sullivan, Cyclone |publisher=AllMusic |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> (2011, number 7 on the Billboard Blues chart, July 30, 2011).<ref name=\"cyclone\">{{cite magazine | url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2011-07-30/blues-albums |title=Quinn Sullivan, Cyclone |magazine=Billboard |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Later in 2013, Hambridge would do the same on [[Quinn Sullivan (musician)|Quinn Sullivan]]'s release ''Getting There'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/getting-there-mw0002550681 |title=Getting There |publisher=AllMusic |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> which charted at 38 on the Billboard Blues Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/277262/quinn-sullivan/chart|title=Billboard Blues Charts \u2013 Getting There |magazine=Billboard |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, Hambridge earned his second [[Grammy Award for Best Blues Album]] for his contributions as a musician, producer, composer and mixer on [[Buddy Guy]]'s [[Born to Play Guitar]].\n\nIn 2016, Hambridge produced [[Mike Zito]]'s album, ''Make Blues Not War'',<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.allmusic.com/album/make-blues-not-war-mw0002985066  |title= Mike Zito \u2013 Make Blues Not War |publisher=AllMusic |year=2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> which debuted at number 1 on the [[Billboard Chart]] on December 10, 2016<ref>{{cite magazine | url= http://www.billboard.com/artist/311241/mike-zito/chart?sort=position&f=308  |title= Billboard Music Charts \u2013 Mike Zito|magazine=Billboard |year=2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> and earned his seventh [[Grammy Award]] Nomination<ref>{{cite magazine | url= http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7597556/grammys-nominees-complete-list-2017  |title= Grammy Nomination \u2013 Kenny Neal's Bloodline|magazine=Billboard |year=2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref> for his production work on [[Bloodline (Kenny Neal album)|Bloodline]].\n\nHambridge's songs and productions have appeared on a variety of television shows, movies and commercials.  These include \"It Hurt's So Bad\" ([[Susan Tedeschi]]) on [[PBS]]'s ''Austin City Limits'',<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.tvguide.com/detail/tv-show.aspx?tvobjectid=191387&more=ucepisodelist&episodeid=955221|title= TV Guide |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> ''Autumn Hearts'',<ref name=\"autumn\">{{cite web | url= http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/store/movies/title/0,,3788547,00.html |title= Autumn Hearts (motion picture) |work=artistdirect.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> [[VH1]]'s ''Born To Diva'',<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.starpathmusic.com/press_txt.html |title= VH1 Born To Diva |work=starpathmusic.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> [[NBC]]'s ''[[Conan O'Brien]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1442910/filmoyear |title= Conan O'Brien |publisher=IMDb |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> and ''The Late Late Show with Craig Kilborn''.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BLUES,+NOT+BUBBLEGUM%3B+TESDECHI+GOES+FOR+GRAMMY.-a083391601|title= Late Late Show With Craig Kilborn |work=thefreelibrary.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> In addition, \"Rock Me Right\" (Susan Tedeschi) appeared in ''Autumn Hearts'',<ref name=\"autumn\"/> ''[[David Letterman Show]]'', ''NASCAR Rocks II'' (1999),<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/472491/NASCAR-Rocks-II/ |title= NASCAR Rocks II (1999) |work=tcm.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> and ''[[Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.cduniverse.com/search/xx/music/pid/1249806/a/Flintstones+in+Viva+Rock+Vegas,+The.htm |title= Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas |work=cduniverse.com |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> \"I Fell in Love\" (Susan Tedeschi) appeared on the [[Bug (soundtrack)|''Bug'' soundtrack]].<ref>{{cite web | url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1442910/filmoyear |title= I Fell in Love |publisher=IMDb |year=2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Plus, \"Road Trip\" and \"I Got A New Car\" (Tom Hambridge) appeared in the movie ''[[Cars (soundtrack)|Cars]]''. \"Flying By\" ([[Billy Ray Cyrus]]) appeared in the film, ''Flying By''.\n\nHambridge has performed multiple times at the [[White House]].  On February 21, 2012, he joined [[Buddy Guy]], [[Keb Mo]], [[Susan Tedeschi]], [[Derek Trucks]], [[Mick Jagger]], [[B. B. King]] and others in a performance for the White House's \"Red, White and Blues\" Black History Month celebration concert.  During the performance, President [[Barack Obama]] provided a brief history of the Blues and accompanied the group during the song \"[[Sweet Home Chicago]]\".  On October 14, 2015, Hambridge returned to the [[White House]] with [[Buddy Guy]], [[Marty Sammon]], [[Trombone Shorty]], [[Carol Burnett]], [[Queen Latifah]], [[MC Lyte]], [[Keb Mo]], [[Smokey Robinson]] and others for \"A Celebration of American Creativity: In Performance at the White House\", commemorating the 50th anniversary of the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]].\n\n==Credits==\n;As leader\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! style=\"text-align: center; font-weight: bold;border: 1px solid #000;\" | Year\n! style=\"text-align: center; font-weight: songwriter and guitarist}}\n{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| image           = bappic.jpg\n| name            = Bap Kennedy\n| birth_name      = Martin Christopher Kennedy\n| birth_date      = {{Birth date |1962|6|17|df=y}}\n| birth_place     = [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland\n| death_date      = {{Death date and age|2016|11|1|1962|6|17|df=y}}\n| death_place     = [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland\n| instrument      = Vocals, guitar, harmonica\n| genre           = {{hlist|Rock|[[country music|country]]|[[Americana music|americana]]|[[blues music|blues]]|[[folk music|folk]]|[[soul music|soul]]}}\n| occupation      = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active    = 1978\u20132016\n| label           = {{hlist|Lonely Street Discs|[[Proper Records]]|[[Loose Music]]}}\n| past_member_of = {{hlist|[[Energy Orchard]]|[[Van Morrison]]|[[Steve Earle]]|[[Mark Knopfler]]}}\n| website         = [http://www.bapkennedy.com Bap Kennedy official website]\n}}\n\n'''Martin Christopher Kennedy''' (17 June 1962 \u2013 1 November 2016), known as '''Bap Kennedy''', was a singer-songwriter from [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland.<ref name=\"artistdirect\">{{cite web|url=http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/music/artist/bio/0,,661979,00.html|publisher=artistdirect.com|title=Bap Kennedy biography|accessdate=26 January 2009}}</ref> He was noted for his collaborations with [[Steve Earle]], [[Van Morrison]], [[Shane MacGowan]]<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> and [[Mark Knopfler]],<ref name=\"Mark Knopfler\">{{cite web|url= http://www.markknopfler.com/discography/bap-kennedy|publisher=markknopfler.com|title=Mark Knopfler discography|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> as well as for writing the song \"Moonlight Kiss\" which was on the soundtrack for the film ''[[Serendipity (film)|Serendipity]]''.<ref name=\"newsletter\">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/what-s-on/music/it-was-fun-to-revisit-my-more-upbeat-self-1-5835720|publisher=newsletter.com|title=Bap Kennedy interview|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nKennedy was in the rock band [[Energy Orchard]]<ref name=\"biography\">{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/bio.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Biography: Bap Kennedy|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> for many years and also recorded a number of well-received solo albums including ''[[Domestic Blues]]'', ''[[The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)|The Big Picture]]'', ''[[The Sailor's Revenge]],'' ''Let's Start Again'' and ''Reckless Heart''.<ref name=\"biography\"/> During his solo career, Kennedy performed, wrote and recorded songs with artists such as [[Steve Earle]] (on ''Domestic Blues''), [[Van Morrison]] (on ''The Big Picture'') and [[Mark Knopfler]] (on ''The Sailor's Revenge'').<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> Following the releases of ''The Big Picture'' and ''The Sailor's Revenge'', he toured the US and Europe with [[Mark Knopfler]] of [[Dire Straits]],<ref name=\"biography\"/> who also produced Kennedy's 2012 album ''The Sailor's Revenge''.<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/>\n\n==Musical career==\n===Early musical career and 10 Past 7 (1978\u201387)===\nKennedy's first band was the punk band Sellout formed in 1978 at age 16.  The band was formed to support rock group Uncle Waldo, playing in a local [[Belfast]] club.<ref name=\"cdbaby\">{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/bapkennedy1|publisher=cdbaby.com|title=The Big Picture|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nIn 1980 after having played in several other local bands, Kennedy formed the band 10 past 7,<ref name=\"triste\">{{cite web|url=http://www.triste.co.uk/artkennedy.htm|publisher=triste.com|title=Bap Kennedy \u2013 too long in exile|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> with whom he received his first national recognition when they appeared on [[Channel 4]] music show [[The Tube (1982 TV series)|The Tube]] in 1983.<ref name=\"Irish rock\">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishrock.org/irodb/bands/tenpastseven.html|publisher=irishrock.org|title=10 Past 7|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> The band was managed by Mark Kelly, {{small|[[Order of the British Empire|MBE]]}}.<ref name=\"biography\"/> 10 Past 7 were signed to the [[Good Vibrations (record label)|Good Vibrations]] record label by [[Terri Hooley]]<ref name=\"Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014\">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/bap-kennedy-brian-is-more-showbiz-than-me-30049175.html |work=The Belfast Telegraph|title=Brian is more showbiz than me|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> \u2013 who had discovered [[The Undertones]] several years earlier<ref name=\"Belfast Telegraph July 2011\">{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/story-of-terri-hooley-belfasts-godfather-of-punk-to-hit-silver-screen-28640706.html|work=The Belfast Telegraph|title=Story of Terri Hooley, Belfast's godfather of punk, to hit silver screen|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> \u2013 and they released two singles<ref name=\"Irish rock\"/> before disbanding when Bap left Belfast for London to pursue a recording contract.<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\n===Energy Orchard (1987\u201396)===\n{{Main|Energy Orchard}}\nIn 1987, after moving to London, Kennedy formed the band [[Energy Orchard]], for whom he was the rhythm guitarist, lead singer and primary songwriter.<ref name=\"biography\"/> Although the band was based in London, all of its members had originally come from Belfast like Kennedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/394165-Energy-Orchard|publisher=discogs|title=Energy Orchard|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> [[MCA Records]] gave the band a major record deal in 1988 and they would go on to release two albums with the label, before signing with [[Transatlantic Records|Transatlantic]] for a further two studio albums as well as the live album ''Orchardville''.<ref name=\"cdbaby\"/>\n\nEnergy Orchard went on to establish themselves as regulars on the live scene in London, including a performance at the first London [[Fleadh Cheoil|Fleadh]] in 1990.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/event/1125119+Fleadh+1990|publisher=last.fm|title=Fleadh 1990|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> The band also toured extensively throughout the UK, Europe and America, including several support slots with [[Van Morrison]], [[Steve Earle]] and [[Jimmy Barnes]].<ref name=\"biography\"/> Energy Orchard disbanded in 1996 with a farewell London gig on [[St Patrick's Day]] which would be recorded for the live album ''Orchardville''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-interview|publisher=nodepression.com|title=Bap Kennedy interview|accessdate=3 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703012528/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-interview|archive-date=3 July 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\n==Solo career==\n===''Domestic Blues'' and Steve Earle (1998\u20132000)===\n{{Main|Domestic Blues}}\nAfter Energy Orchard split up, Kennedy received a phone call from [[Steve Earle]], who offered to produce Kennedy's first solo record.<ref name=\"Loose\">{{cite web|url=http://loosemusic.com/bapkennedy/index.html|publisher=loosemusic.com|title=Bap Kennedy: The Big Picture|accessdate=27 January 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222080116/http://www.loosemusic.com/bapkennedy/index.html|archivedate=22 December 2008}}</ref> Shortly afterwards, Kennedy joined him in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and recorded his first solo album.<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/>\n\n''[[Domestic Blues]]'', which was released in 1998, was produced by the \"Twang Trust\" of Earle and [[Ray Kennedy (country singer)|Ray Kennedy]],<ref name=\"allmusic Domestic Blues\">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/domestic-blues-mw0000598926|publisher=AllMusic|title=Domestic Blues|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> and Earle played guitar and sang backing vocals on the record.<ref name=\"biography\"/> The album also features [[slide guitar]] player [[Jerry Douglas]], guitarist [[Peter Rowan]] and singer [[Nanci Griffith]] amongst its session musicians.<ref name=\"Loose\"/>\n\nAll the songs on ''Domestic Blues'' were written by Kennedy except ''Angel is the Devil'' which was written by Earle.<ref name=\"biography\"/> Earle was later to describe Kennedy as \"the best songwriter I ever saw\".<ref name=\"biography\"/> The album was released on Earle's record label [[E-Squared Records|E-Squared]] and received generally favorable reviews.<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/><ref name=\"allmusic Domestic Blues\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-domestic-blues.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About Domestic Blues|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120002203/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-domestic-blues.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref> It was also a commercial success, charting at number eight on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\nSeveral songs from the album were used for movie soundtracks, including ''Vampire'' appearing in the soundtrack for the [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] nominated<ref name=\"IMDB\">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0203230/awards|publisher=IMDb|title=You Can Count on Me \u2013 Awards|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> film ''[[You Can Count on Me]]'',<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> which also won the Grand Jury Prize at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].<ref name=\"IMDB\"/> Three other songs from ''Domestic Blues'' were also used in the film ''[[Southie (film)|Southie]]''.<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\nIn 2012, the album's title track was used as the theme song for [[BBC Radio 4]] comedy ''Happy Tuesdays''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2012/06/bbc-radio-4-adopts-domestic-blues.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=BBC Radio 4 adopts Domestic Blues|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> After the release of ''Domestic Blues'', Kennedy toured with Steve Earle<ref name=\"biography\"/> alongside other artists on the E-Squared label, including [[Cheri Knight]] and [[The V-Roys]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earledisc.com/SED_E_Squared.htm|publisher=earledisc.com|title=E-Squared records discography|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103070509/http://earledisc.com/SED_E_Squared.htm|archivedate=3 November 2014}}</ref>\n\nWhile he was in Nashville, Kennedy developed a keen interest in the music of [[Hank Williams]], whom Kennedy described as his \"favourite song writer\"<ref name=\"newsletter\"/> and a major influence. After he had finished recording ''Domestic Blues'', Kennedy recorded an album of Hank Williams covers entitled ''Hillbilly Shakespeare'',<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> which featured [[pedal steel guitar]] playing from [[B.J. Cole]].<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Hillbilly Shakespeare|others=Bap Kennedy|year=1999|page=4|type=CD}}</ref> The album had a very limited release as the first record on Kennedy's own label, Lonely Street Discs.<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/><ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\n===''Lonely Street'', ''Serendipity'' and ''Moonlight Kiss'' (2000\u201305)===\nAfter returning to the UK, Kennedy briefly managed an [[Elvis impersonator]] named The King, and was the producer for The King's album ''Gravelands'' \u2013 a collection of songs by other deceased artists performed in the style of [[Elvis Presley]].<ref name=\"cdbaby\"/> The record became a firm favourite of [[John Peel]] and the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]]. Kennedy's continued interest in the music of [[Hank Williams]] and [[Elvis Presley]] led to him writing ''Lonely Street'', a [[concept album]] based on the lives of his two musical heroes.<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/>\n\nThe album, which was released in 2000 on Kennedy's Lonely Street Discs label,<ref name=\"cdbaby\"/> features bass guitar playing by [[Herbie Flowers]],<ref name=\"biography\"/> who is noted for playing the famous bass line on [[Lou Reed]]'s hit song [[Walk on the Wild Side (Lou Reed song)|Walk on the Wild Side]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/bass/the-25-best-basslines-of-all-time-509265/10/1|work=MusicRadar|title=The 25 best basslines of all time (page 11 of 25)|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> It received generally positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/lonely-street-mw0000061425|publisher=AllMusic|title=Lonely Street \u2013 Bap Kennedy|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-lonely-street.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About Lonely Street|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131118195406/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-lonely-street.html|archivedate=18 November 2013}}</ref> Kennedy's ballad \"Moonlight Kiss\" from the album was later used in the soundtrack for hit Hollywood movie [[Serendipity (movie)|Serendipity]] (starring [[John Cusack]] and [[Kate Beckinsale]]).<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\nFollowing the release of Lonely Street, Kennedy spent several years touring,<ref name=\"Boogaloo songkick\">{{cite web|url= http://www.songkick.com/concerts/10843678-pete-doherty-at-boogaloo|publisher=songkick.com|title=Pete Doherty at Boogaloo|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"Putney songkick\">{{cite web|url= http://www.songkick.com/concerts/7448786-bap-kennedy-at-half-moon-putney|publisher=songkick.com|title=Bap Kennedy at Half Moon, Putney|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> including performances with [[Shane MacGowan]] of [[The Pogues]] and [[Pete Doherty]] of [[The Libertines]],<ref name=\"Boogaloo songkick\"/> and at the respected [[The Half Moon, Putney|Half Moon, Putney]],<ref name=\"Putney songkick\"/> which also regularly held the [[Rolling Stones]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.halfmoon.co.uk/static/music|publisher=halfmoon.co.uk|title=The Half Moon|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212065858/http://www.halfmoon.co.uk/static/music|archivedate=12 February 2013}}</ref>\n\n===''The Big Picture'', Van Morrison and Shane MacGowan (2005\u201309)===\n{{Main|The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)}}\n[[The Pogues]]' lead singer [[Shane MacGowan]] provided guest vocals on Kennedy's next album, [[The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)|The Big Picture]], with MacGowan providing lead vocals on the last verse of Kennedy's song \"On the Mighty Ocean Alcohol\".<ref name=\"fame magazine\">{{cite web|url=http://www.famemagazine.co.uk/2009/06/05/bap-kennedy-goes-to-glasto/|publisher=famemagazine.co.uk|title= Bap Kennedy Goes to Glasto|accessdate=5 June 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629175600/http://www.famemagazine.co.uk/2009/06/05/bap-kennedy-goes-to-glasto|archivedate=29 June 2009}}</ref>\n\nThe late [[Carolyn Cassady]], another guest vocalist on the album,<ref name=\"Loose\"/> was the basis of the character Camille in [[Jack Kerouac]]'s book ''[[On the Road]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/carolyn-cassady-camille-in-kerouacs-novel-on-the-road-8835425.html|work=The Independent|title=Carolyn Cassady: 'Camille' in Kerouac's novel 'On The Road'|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> At the end of Kennedy's song Moriarty's Blues, Cassady gave a reading from her own book ''[[Off the Road]]''.<ref name=\"biography\"/> \"Moriarty's Blues\" is a ballad about the ''On the Road'' character Dean Moriarty,<ref name=\"biography\"/> which was based on Cassady's husband [[Neal Cassady|Neal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jan/18/beat-poets-cassady-kerouac-ginsberg|work=The Guardian|title=Neal Cassady: Drug-taker. Bigamist. Family man.|date=18 January 2011|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nThe Big Picture was also a return to working with [[Van Morrison]],<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> who had supported Kennedy since his [[Energy Orchard]] days.<ref name=\"biography\"/> The album was recorded at Morrison's studio and featured the song Milky Way which was co-written by Morrison and Kennedy.<ref name=\"fame magazine\"/> The musicians appearing on the album include [[pedal steel]] guitarist [[B.J. Cole]] and guitarist James Walbourne,<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=The Big Picture|others=Bap Kennedy|year=2005|page=2|type=CD}}</ref> who is a member of rock group [[The Pretenders]].<ref name=\"biography\"/> The album was released in 2005 to generally positive reviews.<ref name=\"Loose\"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-big-picture.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About The Big Picture|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120001102/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-big-picture.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref>\n\nAfter the release of the album, Kennedy was approached by former [[Dire Straits]] frontman [[Mark Knopfler]], who asked Kennedy to play as Knopfler's support artist.<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> This led to Kennedy working as the support artist and special guest for Knopfler's tours of the US and Europe, including a five night stint at London's [[Royal Albert Hall]].<ref name=\"fame magazine\"/>\n\n===''Howl On'' and Glastonbury(2009\u20132012)===\n{{Main|Howl On}}\nKennedy's 2009 album ''[[Howl On]]'' was, like ''Lonely Street'', a [[concept album]] based upon a real life subject which Kennedy was interested in. ''Howl On'' was a look back at the [[Space Race]] of the late 1960s, with Kennedy examining the lives and backgrounds of the astronauts and scientists who worked on the [[Apollo program]].<ref name=\"fame magazine\"/>\n\nThe only cover on the album,<ref name=\"Howl on notes\">{{cite AV media notes|title=Howl On|others=Bap Kennedy|year=2009|page=Inside album front cover|type=CD}}</ref> [[Hey Joe]] was also chosen as a nod to this time period, as it had been the last song performed by [[Jimi Hendrix]] at the [[Woodstock Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/jimi-hendrix/1969/max-yasgurs-farm-bethel-ny-13d6b511.html|publisher=setlist.fm|title=Jimi Hendrix setlist at woodstock|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nThe song also features guest guitarist [[Henry McCullough]],<ref name=\"fame magazine\"/> who was, as a member of [[Joe Cocker]]'s band, the only Irishman to play at Woodstock.<ref name=\"McCullough\">{{cite web|url= http://ultimateclassicrock.com/wings-and-joe-cocker-guitarist-henry-mccullough-suffered-brain-damage/|publisher=ultimateclassicrock.com|title=Wings and Joe Cocker guitarist Henry McCullough suffered brain damage |accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> McCullough also worked with [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Wings (band)|Wings]].<ref name=\"McCullough\"/>\n\nHowl on received generally positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jul/19/bap-kennedy-howl-on|work=The Guardian|title=Bap Kennedy \u2013 Howl On|date=18 July 2009|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=\"about Howl On\">{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-howl-on.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About Howl On|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120001055/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-howl-on.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref> The album was followed by a successful tour of the UK, Europe and America, including the [[South by South West]] festival<ref name=\"biography\"/> and a performance at the 2009 [[Glastonbury Festival]].<ref name=\"fame magazine\"/>\n\n===''The Sailor's Revenge'' and Mark Knopfler (2012\u201314)===\n{{Main|The Sailor's Revenge}}\nKennedy recorded a new album in early 2011, entitled ''[[The Sailor's Revenge]]'', produced by former [[Dire Straits]] frontman [[Mark Knopfler]]<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> at Knopfler's [[British Grove Studios]] in London.<ref name=\"Guy Fletcher\">{{cite web|url=http://www.guyfletcher.co.uk/index.php/diary/Bap_Kennedy_sessions |publisher=guyfletcher.co.uk |title=Bap Kennedy sessions |accessdate=3 March 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215084628/http://www.guyfletcher.co.uk/index.php/diary/Bap_Kennedy_sessions |archivedate=15 December 2012 }}</ref> The album was a close collaboration between Kennedy and Knopfler, with the two artists having worked together on the project for 2 years. As well as producing the record, Knopfler had been heavily involved in choosing which songs to record for the album,<ref name=\"biography\"/> and also played guitar on multiple songs and sang backing vocals for the song \"Celtic Sea\".<ref name=\"TSR notes\">{{cite AV media notes|title=The Sailor's Revenge|others=Bap Kennedy|year=2012|page=Inside album front cover|type=CD}}</ref>\n\nThe album features several members of Knopfler's touring band, such as [[Glenn Worf]], [[Guy Fletcher]], [[John McCusker]], [[Michael McGoldrick]] and [[Richard Bennett (guitarist)|Richard Bennett]]. Also playing on the album were session musician [[Jerry Douglas]], who had previously worked with Kennedy on ''[[Domestic Blues]]'', and James Walbourne of [[The Pretenders]], who had played on Kennedy's 2005 album ''[[The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)|The Big Picture]]''.<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\n''The Sailor's Revenge'' was released in 2012 on [[Proper Records]] and received widespread critical acclaim internationally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/162141-bap-kennedy-the-sailors-revenge|work=PopMatters|title=Bap Kennedy \u2013 The Sailor's Revenge|date=3 September 2012|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2012/06/pittsburgh-daily-news-usa-highly-commends-the-sailors-revenge.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Pittsburgh Daily News USA highly commends TSR|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> including No 1 \u2013 Best of 2012 in influential American magazine ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-sailors-revenge.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About The Sailor's Revenge|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120001107/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-sailors-revenge.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref> where it was described as \"truly a masterpiece from a man who is finally comfortable in his place in the world \u2013 The Celtic [[Blood on the Tracks]]\".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-the-sailor-s-revenge-disc-review|publisher=nodepression.com|title=Bap Kennedy \u2013 The Sailor's Revenge (disc review)|accessdate=3 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309113256/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-the-sailor-s-revenge-disc-review|archive-date=9 March 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> It was also listed by ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' in the Top 10 [[Americana (music)|Americana]] albums of 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2013/01/the-sailors-revenge-makes-mojos-top-10-for-2012-americana.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=The Sailor's Revenge makes Mojo's Top 10 for 2012 Americana|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nThe album was supported by tours of the US, UK and Europe with Mark Knopfler.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2013/07/bap-mark-knopfler-nimes-france.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Bap & Mark Knopfler \u2013 Nimes, France|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2013/06/bap-steve-earle.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Bap & Steve Earle \u2013 old friends reunited!|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\n===''Let's Start Again'' (2014\u20132016)===\nAfter the Celtic melancholy of ''The Sailor's Revenge'', Kennedy moved to an upbeat Americana style for the follow-up ''Let's Start Again''.<ref name=\"Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014\"/> The album, which Kennedy recorded in his native [[Northern Ireland]],<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> was produced by Mudd Wallace,<ref name=\"Irish World\">{{cite web|url=http://www.theirishworld.com/?p=6136|publisher=theirishworld.com|title=A Belfast Bap|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> who produced several albums for Northern Irish [[alternative rock]] band [[Therapy?]].<ref name=\"Mudd Wallace discogs\">{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/539388-Mudd-Wallace|publisher=discogs|title=Mudd Wallace|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> Wallace was a long-time friend of Kennedy and had worked as producer for Kennedy's early band 10 Past 7.<ref name=\"Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014\"/> Let's Start Again uses local Northern Irish session musicians, and features several musicians from Kennedy's live band, including his wife Brenda Kennedy, who plays bass guitar and sings backing vocals on the album.<ref name=\"Irish World\"/>\n\nThe album had a full international release on CD and [[vinyl record|vinyl]] formats by [[Proper Records]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2014/02/lets-start-again-international-release-dates.html \n|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Let's Start Again international release dates|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> and has received widespread critical acclaim including a 5 star review from [[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/reviews.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Reviews|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140321203701/http://www.bapkennedy.com/reviews.html|archivedate=21 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-let-s-start-again|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140304095143/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-let-s-start-again|url-status=dead|archive-date=4 March 2014|publisher=nodepression.com|title=Bap Kennedy \u2013 Let's Start Again (album review)|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\n=== ''Reckless Heart'' (2016) ===\nKennedy's final album, Reckless Heart, was recorded in early 2016, only a few weeks before his diagnosis.<ref name=\"biography\" /> Like Let's Start Again, Reckless Heart was recorded in Northern Ireland and used several musicians from Kennedy's live band, including his wife Brenda.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Reckless Heart (liner notes)|last=Bap Kennedy}}</ref>\n\nThe album was released posthumously by Kennedy's label Lonely Street Discs, in conjunction with Last Chance Records in the US and by at the Helm in the UK and internationally.<ref name=\"biography\" /> It has received widespread critical acclaim.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/reckless-heart-review.html|title=Reckless Heart Review|website=Bap Kennedy|access-date=12 February 2017|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213090423/http://www.bapkennedy.com/reckless-heart-review.html|archivedate=13 February 2017}}</ref>\n\n==Personal life==\nMartin Christopher Kennedy was born on 17 June 1962<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/> to Lily and Jim Kennedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/BapKennedy/photos/a.231500228007.134233.128493593007/10151926758983008/?type=1|publisher=facebook.com|title=Bap Kennedy facebook post|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=June 2020}}\n\nHe was the brother of [[Brian Kennedy (singer)|Brian Kennedy]]. The family grew up on the [[Falls Road, Belfast]], in the 1970s,<ref name=\"biography\"/> where he got his nickname of Bap, as a childhood reference to the rolls (or \"baps\") of bread sold by local firm Kennedy's Bakery.<ref name=\"Irish World\"/>\n\nKennedy grew up in West Belfast at the height of [[the Troubles]],<ref name=\"Irish World\"/> and his close friend and 10 Past 7 manager Mark Kelly,{{small|[[Order of the British Empire|MBE]]}} lost both legs in a no-warning bomb in Belfast in 1976.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surrey.ac.uk/mediacentre/press/2012/81136_unique_research_reveals_the_forgotten_needs_of_those_physically_injured_victims_of_the_troubles_and_their_families.htm \n|publisher=surrey.ac.uk|title=Unique research reveals the forgotten needs of those physically injured victims of the troubles and their families|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>\n\nKennedy left [[Northern Ireland]] in 1985<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/category/pressinterviews/1.html \n|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Joe Giltrapp interviews Bap Kennedy|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> and worked as a [[labourer]] on building sites in London prior to becoming a professional musician.<ref name=\"Culture Northern Ireland\">{{cite web|url=http://www.culturenorthernireland.org/article.aspx?art_id=65 |publisher=culturenorthernireland.org |title=My Cultural Life: Bap Kennedy |accessdate=3 March 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080310234504/http://www.culturenorthernireland.org/article.aspx?art_id=65 |archivedate=10 March 2008 }}</ref> While living in England, Kennedy became a qualified diamond [[gemology|gemmologist]], accredited by the [[Gemmological Association of Great Britain]].<ref name=\"Culture Northern Ireland\"/>\n\nIn 2007, Kennedy moved back to his native Northern Ireland.<ref name=\"biography\"/> Shortly after returning, Kennedy hosted a songwriting workshop, where he met author and former lawyer Brenda Boyd, who was participating in the workshop. The two soon became a couple, and they were married in 2008.<ref name=\"fame magazine\"/> Brenda, who has written several advice books for parents of children with [[autism]] and [[Asperger syndrome]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/weekend/we-make-sweet-music-together-28480290.html|work=The Belfast Telegraph|title=We Make Sweet Music Together|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> has since sung backing vocals on four of Kennedy's albums \u2013 ''Howl On'',<ref name=\"Howl on notes\"/> ''The Sailor's Revenge'',<ref name=\"TSR notes\"/> ''Let's Start Again'' and ''Reckless Heart''<ref name=\"biography\"/> \u2013 and was also a regular member of Kennedy's live band, as his bass guitarist and backing singer.<ref name=\"artistdirect\"/>\n\nThrough his marriage to Brenda, Kennedy was also stepfather to Christine White and Kenneth Hall, who is also an author, having written about his experience as a child with [[Asperger syndrome]] in ''Asperger Syndrome, the Universe and Everything''.<ref name=\"biography\"/> As a result of his family's links with [[autism]] and [[Asperger's syndrome]], Kennedy became co-patron (with his wife) of the charity Autism NI in 2010.<ref name=\"Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014\"/> Kennedy later revealed on his blog that he too had been diagnosed with Asperger's Syndrome, which he credited as being \"the engine of [his] creativity\".<ref name=\":0\" /> Outside of music, Kennedy had a keen interest in the [[Apollo space program]],<ref name=\"about Howl On\"/> which would be the inspiration for Kennedy's 2009 album ''Howl On''.<ref name=\"biography\"/>\n\n==Cancer battle==\nIn May 2016, Kennedy started a blog on his personal website, detailing his progress after a sudden cancer diagnosis.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/baps-blog.html|title=Bap's blog|website=Bap Kennedy|access-date=12 February 2017}}</ref> He died on 1 November 2016 in Belfast in hospice care from [[Pancreatic cancer|pancreatic]] and [[bowel cancer]]. He had been receiving palliative care at Belfast's Marie Curie clinic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/belfast-news/west-belfast-singer-bap-kennedy-12113184|title=Tributes after West Belfast singer Bap Kennedy dies at 54|first=Sarah|last=Scott|date=1 November 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Recorded with Energy Orchard===\n*''[[Energy Orchard (album)|Energy Orchard]]'' (1990)\n*''[[Stop the Machine]]'' (1992)\n*''[[Shinola (Energy Orchard album)|Shinola]]'' (1993)\n*''[[Pain Killer (Energy Orchard album)|Pain Killer]]'' (1995)\n*''Orchardville'' (1996)\n\n===Solo & Bladdered'' (2000)\n*''Long Time a Comin''': The Story So Far (2002)\n*''Moriarty's Blues (Standard Edition EP ''and'' Special Edition EP)'' (2005)\n*''[[The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)|The Big
