present.\n\n==Other ventures==\n===Dead & Company===\n{{main|Dead & Company}}\nSince 2015, Mayer has been touring with [[Bob Weir]], [[Bill Kreutzmann]] and [[Mickey Hart]] of the [[Grateful Dead]]. Founding bassist [[Phil Lesh]] has notably declined to participate in the project, although he has performed with Mayer on a few occasions since Dead & Company began.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Mayer with Phil Lesh & Friends at Terrapin Crossroads|url=https://www.jambase.com/article/john-mayer-with-phil-lesh-friends-at-terrapin-crossroads|website=Jambase|access-date=September 10, 2018|date=August 6, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828071145/https://www.jambase.com/article/john-mayer-with-phil-lesh-friends-at-terrapin-crossroads|archive-date=August 28, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> The role of bassist in Dead & Company has instead been played by [[Oteil Burbridge]] of the [[Allman Brothers Band]]. [[Jeff Chimenti]], who has toured with the various spin-offs of the Dead since the 1990s, is the group's keyboardist. \n \nAlthough Mayer had been familiar with the music of the Grateful Dead since at least high school, he began to develop a strong interest in their music in 2011 after hearing their song ''[[Althea (Grateful Dead song)|Althea]]'' by chance on [[Pandora radio]]. In 2015, while the Dead's ''[[Fare Thee Well: Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead|Fare Thee Well]]'' shows with [[Trey Anastasio]] were also being planned, Mayer performed \"Althea\" with Weir on [[The Late Late Show (U.S. TV series)|The Late Late Show]], along with \"[[Truckin']]\". Weir was impressed with Mayer's take on the material and began planning to work with him after the Fare Thee Well shows, despite them being billed as something of finale for the band and its legacy. Weir discussed the genesis of the band and his thoughts about working with Mayer in an interview with ''Rolling Stone'' in 2016:\n\n{{Blockquote|I was doing preliminary get-togethers with Trey, kicking around the material. Trey is also a monster musician. If I had to make a broad categorization, John is a classicist by nature. Trey is more of an iconoclast. They're both explorers, someone who's happy to break tradition. Juxtaposing Trey's take on the material with the insights John brings got me looking at all of the songs afresh.\n\nI look forward to playing with Trey again, any old time. But I am really eager to get back out with John-boy and chase the music around, get to know each other. When that dream came to me, it was at about that point that I started to realize that I was feeling comfortable with knowing that John had moved, musically speaking \u2013 being able to intuit the songs. We were feeling each other out on a new level, several bars down the road.<ref name=\"FRICKE\">{{cite magazine |last1=Fricke |first1=David |title=Bob Weir on Dead & Company's Future, John Mayer's Strengths |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/bob-weir-on-dead-companys-future-john-mayers-classicist-style-50971/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=16 October 2018 |date=31 May 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828071449/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/bob-weir-on-dead-companys-future-john-mayers-classicist-style-50971/ |archive-date=August 28, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>}}\n\nThe thought of pop singer Mayer stepping in for [[Jerry Garcia]] was met with some initial skepticism by both fans and music critics, but the shows have since been well received.<ref name=\"uproxx\">{{cite web |title=In Praise Of John Mayer's Unlikely Second Life As A Jam Band Hero |url=https://uproxx.com/music/john-mayer-dead-and-company-jam-band-reinvention/ |website=UPROXX |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=July 6, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828134359/https://uproxx.com/music/john-mayer-dead-and-company-jam-band-reinvention/ |archive-date=August 28, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> The band continues to tour 2022 and has considered recording a studio album consisting of songs from the Grateful Dead catalog and potentially some originals. In a 2017 interview with ''Rolling Stone'', Lesh praised the band's performances and explained his decision not to take part:\n{{Blockquote|\"I think they're doing a great job. They're bringing the music to the people just like we always wanted to do, and I commend them for it. I hope they're having a good time. It's not something I could do myself, I'm done with that kind of touring.'<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Phil Lesh on Grateful Dead \"Long Strange Trip\" doc: \"it's not the whole story.\"|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/phil-lesh-on-grateful-dead-doc-long-strange-trip-its-not-the-whole-story-110241/|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=10 September 2018|date=May 25, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180910095121/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/phil-lesh-on-grateful-dead-doc-long-strange-trip-its-not-the-whole-story-110241/|archive-date=September 10, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>}}\n\n===Author===\nWith the June 2004 issue of ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', Mayer began a column called \"Music Lessons with John Mayer\".<ref>Newman, Melinda (April 17, 2004), \"John Mayer Tries Hand At New Instrument\". ''Billboard''. '''116''' (16):13.</ref> Each article featured a lesson and his views on various topics, both of personal and popular interest. In the August 2005 issue, he invited readers to create music for orphaned lyrics he had written.<ref name=contest>Mayer, John (September 2005), [http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 \"The Giveaway: John Mayer's Songwriting Contest\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105182915/http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 |date=November 5, 2013 }} ''Esquire''. '''144''' (3):80.</ref> The winner was Tim Fagan of [[Los Angeles]] as announced in the following January's issue.<ref name=winner>Mayer, John (January 2006), [http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 \"Tim Fagan Is A Winner\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105182915/http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 |date=November 5, 2013 }}. ''Esquire''. '''145''' (1): p. 38.</ref>\n\nAs social media gained momentum in the 2000s, Mayer became increasingly active online, and maintained four blogs: a [[Myspace]] page, a blog at his official site, another at Honeyee.com, one at [[tumblr]], and a [[photoblog]] at StunningNikon.com. He was particularly prolific on [[Twitter]], where he was noted for authoring his own posts, and he amassed 3.7 million followers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/SHOWBIZ/Music/09/14/john.mayer.twitter/index.html|title=Mayer to tweet no more - CNN.com|website=www.cnn.com|language=en|access-date=April 14, 2020}}</ref><ref name=MandS/> Although his posts often dealt with career-related matters, they also included jokes, videos, photos, and eventually what he called the \"maintenance of vapor\"\u2014or misguided, personal responses to the media.<ref name=DIEHL/> On January 23, 2008, he posted the quote \"There is danger in theoretical speculation of battle, in prejudice, in false reasoning, in pride, in [[wikt:braggadocio|braggadocio]]. There is one safe resource, the return to nature.\";{{cref|c}} all the previous blog entries were deleted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnmayer.com/blog/john/200801 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102234004/http://www.johnmayer.com/blog/john/200801 |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 2, 2008 |title=johnmayer.com |access-date=May 2, 2017}}</ref> On September 14, 2010, he deleted his personal Twitter account.<ref name=DIEHL/>\n\nIn the mid-2000s, he did comedy sporadically,<ref name=\"Daly\">Daly, Steven (December 2009), [http://www.details.com/celebrities-entertainment/cover-stars/200912/singer-musician-cover-star-half-of-my-heart-john-mayer?currentPage=6 \"John Mayer Thinks With His Pick\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091128055033/http://www.details.com/celebrities-entertainment/cover-stars/200912/singer-musician-cover-star-half-of-my-heart-john-mayer?currentPage=6|date=November 28, 2009}}. ''Details''. Retrieved February 8, 2010.</ref> making random appearances at the famed [[Comedy Cellar]] in New York and at other venues.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lehner |first1=Marla |title=John Mayer Performs Raunchy Stand-Up |url=https://people.com/celebrity/john-mayer-performs-raunchy-stand-up/ |website=PEOPLE.com |access-date=May 6, 2022 |language=en |date=May 22, 2007}}</ref> He stated that it helped him write better, but that increased media attention made him too careful in his technique.<ref name=RS06/> He has since said he has no plans to return to it.<ref name=patrickdoyle/>\n\n===Watch collector===\nMayer is an avid collector of watches, a pastime that he says keeps him \"sane\". His collection\u2014which he values in the \"tens of millions\" of dollars<ref name=wrist/>\u2014includes a [[Patek Philippe & Co.#Most expensive|Patek Philippe with a Sky Moon Tourbillion]], a [[Rolex GMT Master]] 116710 BLNR, and an [[International Watch Company|IWC]] Big Pilot Ref 5002, his signature watch.<ref name=wrist/><ref>Clymer, Benjamin and Holloway, Will (September 25, 2013), [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/video-talking-watches-with-john-mayer \"Talking Watches With John Mayer\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402164412/http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/video-talking-watches-with-john-mayer |date=April 2, 2015 }}. Hodinkee. Retrieved March 25, 2015.</ref> He has also served as a juror at the Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Gen\u00e8ve, a competition rewarding timepieces that champion the values of [[Swiss made|Swiss-made]] watches<ref name=wrist/> and writes a column for the [[horology]] website [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/john-mayer-chanel-watch-box Hodinkee].<ref>Williams, Alex (December 20, 2013), [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/22/fashion/Hodinkee-Wristwatches-Benjamin-Clymer.html \"The High Priest of Horology\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170222012136/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/22/fashion/Hodinkee-Wristwatches-Benjamin-Clymer.html |date=February 22, 2017 }}. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved March 24, 2015.</ref> In his column for January 16, 2015, he wrote an open letter to the watch brand IWC, encouraging it to \"embrace [its] heritage, scale the product line down in terms of model variants, and simplify the design language\".<ref>Mayer, John (January 16, 2015), [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-iwc-from-john-mayer \"An Open Letter To IWC, From John Mayer\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905113608/http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-iwc-from-john-mayer |date=September 5, 2015 }}. Hodinkee. Retrieved March 24, 2015.</ref> IWC replied, defending the changes they've made over the years, saying, \"We have a wonderful past, it is true\u2014but in admiring what we achieved thus far, we hope you will feel encouraged to look forward to what we achieve in the future\".<ref>(January 17, 2015), [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-john-mayer--from-iwc \"An Open Letter To John Mayer, From IWC\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503011359/http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-john-mayer--from-iwc |date=May 3, 2015 }}. Hondikee. 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> He appeared as a guest star on the fourth episode of the [[Impractical Jokers (season 10)|tenth season]] of the [[TruTV]] show [[Impractical Jokers]] in 2023.<ref>{{Citation |last=Jost |first=Casey |title=John Mayer |date=2023-03-02 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt26626081/ |access-date=2023-10-31 |series=Impractical Jokers |others=James Murray, Brian Quinn, Sal Vulcano}}</ref>\n\nMayer makes a cameo as a truck driver in the 2014 comedy horror film ''[[Zombeavers]]''.<ref>Zeitchik, Steven (April 21, 2014), \"[https://latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-tribeca-2014-zombeavers-movie-sharknado-20140421-story.html \"Tribeca 2014: 'Zombeavers,' 'Sharknado's' newest friend\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017085446/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-tribeca-2014-zombeavers-movie-sharknado-20140421-story.html |date=October 17, 2015 }}. ''Los Angeles Times''. Retrieved May 20, 2015.</ref> In the 2015 film ''[[Get Hard]]'', he played a version of himself who is disgusted with the \"monetization of the creative process\".<ref name=Mallenbaum>Mallenbaum, Carly (March 30, 2015), [http://entertainthis.usatoday.com/2015/03/30/john-mayer-cameo-get-hard/ \"John Mayer: The king of the cameo\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403023020/http://entertainthis.usatoday.com/2015/03/30/john-mayer-cameo-get-hard/ |date=April 3, 2015 }}. USA Today. Retrieved April 9, 2015.</ref> Mayer also had a small role in the 2022 film ''[[Vengeance (2022 film)|Vengeance]]'', playing a friend of the lead character.\n\n==Instruments and equipment==\nJohn Mayer is a guitar collector and has collaborated with elite guitar companies to design his own instruments. He owns over 200 guitars.<ref name=RS06/>\n\nIn 2003, [[C. F. Martin & Company|Martin Guitars]] gave Mayer his own signature model acoustic guitar called the OM-28 John Mayer.<ref name=OM-28>(2003). [http://www.harmonycentral.com/news/john-mayer-receives-signature-martin-om-guitar \"John Mayer Receives Signature Martin OM Guitar\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402153239/http://www.harmonycentral.com/news/john-mayer-receives-signature-martin-om-guitar |date=April 2, 2015 }}. Retrieved January 29, 2007.</ref> The guitar was limited to a run of only 404, an Atlanta area code.<ref name=martin>''Sounding Board Newsletter'' contributor (2003) [http://www.martinguitar.com/model/item/1259-john-mayer-signature-om.html \"John Mayer Signature OM\"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402112812/http://www.martinguitar.com/model/item/1259-john-mayer-signature-om.html |date=April 2, 2015 }} Martin Guitar. Retrieved March 25, 2015</ref> This model was followed by the release of two [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]] signature [[Fender Stratocaster|Stratocaster]] electric guitars, beginning in 2005. A third Stratocaster, finished in charcoal frost metallic paint with a racing stripe, was also a limited-release, with only 100 guitars made. In January 2006, Martin Guitars released the Martin OMJM John Mayer acoustic guitar. The guitar was intended to have many of the attributes of the Martin OM-28 John Mayer but with a more affordable price tag.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fretbase.com/fretbase/2008/08/john-mayers-sig.html |title=Fretbase, John Mayer's Signature Acoustic Guitar \u2013 the Martin OMJM (2008) |website=Fretbase.com |date=August 4, 2008 |access-date=July 24, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081023154758/http://www.fretbase.com/fretbase/2008/08/john-mayers-sig.html |archive-date=October 23, 2008 }}</ref> In August 2006, Fender started manufacturing SERIES II John Mayer Stratocasters.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}\n\nIn January 2007, Two Rock collaborated with Mayer on custom-designed amps. Only 25 (all signed by Mayer himself) were made available to the public,<ref>[http://two-rock.com/products/mayer \"John Mayer Signature\"] Two-Rock. Retrieved May 10, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070502014433/http://two-rock.com/products/mayer |date=May 2, 2007 }}</ref> along with a 500-run John Mayer signature Fender Stratocaster in Cypress-Mica. Included in the limited Cypress-Mica model was the INCSvsJM [[gig bag]], on which Mayer collaborated on the in-case designs. In 2006, Mayer was estimated to have more than 200 guitars in his personal collection.<ref name=RS06/>\n[[File:John Mayer in Cleveland.jpg|thumb|Mayer playing his signature Black1 Stratocaster in 2008]]\nJohn Mayer's most iconic guitar is the \"Black1\". Conceived after the [[Heavier Things]] tour, Mayer went to Fender Custom Shop with the desire to build a guitar.<ref name=micktaylor/> He was inspired by guitars of famous players the likes of [[Rory Gallagher]] and [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]].<ref name=\"youtube.com\">Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/gLMnWxw1Qpg Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130811004456/http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=related&v=gLMnWxw1Qpg&rl=yes&hl=en&gl=US&client=mv-google&guid= Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLMnWxw1Qpg |title=John Mayer - Black One Story |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=January 5, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref> He sought out masterbuilder John Cruz to help devise the design. In essence, Mayer wanted an all-black version of Stevie Ray Vaughan's \"First Wife\" Stratocaster.<ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/luCzeNjs7rE Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20200219141750/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=luCzeNjs7rE&gl=US&hl=en Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=luCzeNjs7rE |title=Fender Custom Shop Road Show With John Cruz - John Mayer |publisher=YouTube |date=December 3, 2015 |access-date=May 2, 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The guitar is heavily \"relic'd\" to specs very similar to the guitar used by Stevie Ray Vaughan. The Black1 includes a mint pickguard, custom wound pickups, gold hardware, and gold tuners from the SRV Tribute Stratocaster. It was the principal guitar on the ''Continuum'' album. It was notably used on tracks such as \"I Don't Trust Myself With Loving You\", and \"Bold as Love\".<ref name=\"youtube.com\"/> The Black1 has become a trademark to Mayer's music.\n\nThe [[Fender Custom Shop]] made a limited run of 83 replica Black1 Stratocasters, all of which were sold within 24 hours.<ref>{{cite web |last=Laing |first=Rob |url=http://www.musicradar.com/guitarist/fender-custom-shop-john-mayer-black1-340224 |title=Fender Custom Shop John Mayer BLACK1 |work=[[MusicRadar]] |date=December 21, 2010 |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227013052/http://www.musicradar.com/guitarist/fender-custom-shop-john-mayer-black1-340224 |archive-date=February 27, 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> Each one was carefully relic'd by John Cruz. In 2010, Fender announced a production model of Mayer's Black1 guitar.<ref name=micktaylor>Taylor, Mick (May 21, 2010), [http://www.musicradar.com/us/guitarist/john-mayer-interview-251957 \"John Mayer interview\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404230439/http://www.musicradar.com/us/guitarist/john-mayer-interview-251957 |date=April 4, 2015 }}. ''Music Radar''. March 29, 2015.</ref> Un-relic'd production versions of the guitar were produced for a limited run of 500 worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |author=Mike Duffy |url=http://www2.fender.com/experience/fender-tone/introducing-the-john-mayer-special-edition-black1-stratocaster-guitar/ |title=Introducing the John Mayer Special Edition BLACK1 Stratocaster\u00ae Guitar &#124; Fender Tone |website=Fender.com |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170515184339/http://www2.fender.com/experience/fender-tone/introducing-the-john-mayer-special-edition-black1-stratocaster-guitar/ |archive-date=May 15, 2017 |url-status=dead}}</ref> In addition, full production signature Stratocasters were produced in three-tone sunburst and Olympic White finishes.\n\nIn 2014, John Mayer announced that he was no longer a Fender Artist.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://reverb.com/news/john-mayer-announces-split-with-fender |title=John Mayer Announces Split with Fender |website=Reverb.com |date=October 17, 2014 |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827125726/https://reverb.com/news/john-mayer-announces-split-with-fender |archive-date=August 27, 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> As a result, his signature line of guitars was pulled from production. In 2015, Mayer announced that he was collaborating with [[PRS Guitars]]. In March 2016, Mayer and PRS revealed their collaborative project, the Super Eagle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prsguitars.com/supereagle/ |title=PRS Guitars Private Stock Super Eagle |website=PRS Guitars |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170430172057/http://www.prsguitars.com/supereagle/ |archive-date=April 30, 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> This was a limited release from PRS's Private Stock line of instruments and each guitar features ultra-grade woods, abalone inlay, JCF Audio preamps, and a hand-signed sticker by glass-artist [[David Adrian Smith|David Smith]]. Only 100 were produced, each retailing for over $10,000.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Mayer's PRS Private Stock Super Eagle guitar takes flight |url=https://www.musicradar.com/news/guitars/john-mayers-prs-private-stock-super-eagle-guitar-takes-flight-635835 |last=Astley-Brown |first=Michael |date=March 15, 2016 |publisher=[[MusicRadar]]}}</ref> In January 2017 at the [[NAMM Show]], PRS and Mayer announced the J-MOD 100 signature amp.<ref>{{cite web|title=J-MOD 100|url=http://www.prsguitars.com/amplifiers/jmod/j_mod_100_2018/|website=PRS Guitars|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419183236/http://www.prsguitars.com/amplifiers/jmod/j_mod_100_2018/|archive-date=April 19, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=NAMM 2017: PRS and John Mayer Announce J-MOD 100 Signature Amp|url=https://www.guitarworld.com/gear/namm-2017-prs-and-john-mayer-announce-j-mod-100-signature-amp |magazine=Guitar World|access-date=January 17, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207003116/https://www.guitarworld.com/gear/namm-2017-prs-and-john-mayer-announce-j-mod-100-signature-amp|archive-date=February 7, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> In June 2017, the Super Eagle II was revealed, limited to 120 instruments.<ref>{{cite web |title=PRS Guitars Private Stock Super Eagle II|url=https://prsguitars.com/supereagle2/|website=PRS Guitars|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419003031/http://prsguitars.com/supereagle2/|archive-date=April 19, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|title=PRS Guitars Announces John Mayer Limited Edition Private Stock Super Eagle II|url=http://americansongwriter.com/2017/06/prs-guitars-announces-john-mayer-limited-edition-private-stock-super-eagle-ii/ |magazine=American Songwriter|access-date=June 7, 2017|date=June 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170719072101/https://americansongwriter.com/2017/06/prs-guitars-announces-john-mayer-limited-edition-private-stock-super-eagle-ii/|archive-date=July 19, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2018, Martin Guitar announced the limited-release (45 instruments) John Mayer Signature D-45, with list price $14,999.<ref>{{cite web|title=D-45 John Mayer |url=https://www.martinguitar.com/guitars/custom-signature-editions/d-45-john-mayer/|website=martinguitar.com|access-date=April 19, 2018, Mayer's signature [[PRS Silver Sky|Silver Sky]] model was released by PRS, available in four colors.<ref>{{cite web |title=Silver Sky |url=https://prsguitars.com/electrics/bolton/silver_sky |website=PRS Guitars |access-date=April 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419183247/https://prsguitars.com/electrics/bolton/silver_sky |archive-date=April 19, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=PRS Guitars Announces New John Mayer Signature Model: The Silver Sky |url=http://americansongwriter.com/2018/03/prs-guitars-announces-new-john-mayer-signature-model-silver-sky/ |magazine=American Songwriter |access-date=March 6, 2018 |date=March 6, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180314062136/http://americansongwriter.com/2018/03/prs-guitars-announces-new-john-mayer-signature-model-silver-sky/ |archive-date=March 14, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> While ''Music Trade'' called the Silver Sky \"derivative\", it said that all the elements were \"designed from the ground up\" and built with \"attention to detail\".<ref name=\"gaining\">{{cite journal |title=WHY PRS IS GAINING SHARE IN THE GUITAR MARKET |journal=Music Trades |date=October 2018 |volume=116 |issue=9 |pages=56\u201362}}</ref> While acknowledging its similarity to a Stratocaster, Matt Blackett of ''Guitar Player'' magazine ultimately said, \"The Silver Sky absolutely delivers on the promise of being a damn-near-perfect version of this type of guitar.\" The magazine named its \"Editor's Pick\".<ref name=\"blackett\">{{cite journal|last1=Blackett |first1=MATT |date=July 2018|title=Silver Sky John Mayer Signature|journal=Guitar Player |volume=52|issue=7|pages=88\u201389 |url=https://www.guitarplayer.com/gear/prs-sliver-sky-john-mayer-signature |access-date=May 26, 2019}}</ref>\n\n==Reception==\nMayer was featured on the cover of ''Rolling Stone'' (#1020) in February 2007, along with [[John Frusciante]] and [[Derek Trucks]], in an issue lauding the \"New Guitar Gods\". The cover nicknamed him Slowhand Jr., a reference to Eric Clapton.<ref name=RSGG/> Critics, however, often pointed to how safe they felt Mayer's music was. Chris Richards, in a review of a 2017 concert, declared Mayer is \"an amazing guitar player\", albeit doing so \"through clenched teeth\". Richards went on to say that his talent as a guitarist did not make him exempt from criticism of \"his pillow-soft songcraft, the dull sentimentality of his lyrics, or that cuckoo-racist interview he gave to Playboy back in 2010\".<ref name=\"richards\">{{cite news |last1=Richards |first1=Chris |title=He's a stellar guitarist, but his songs are staid |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=April 7, 2017}}</ref> Music writer Steve Baltin commented on this dichotomy, saying that Mayer is \"one of the sharpest and savviest musical minds you will ever encounter\", and added: \"While many have found reasons to dislike Mayer since the beginning of his career, he is a consummate musician's musician, an artist who has been embraced by Eric Clapton, [[Stevie Wonder]] and Buddy Guy among others.\"<ref name=\"baltin\">{{cite web |last1=Baltin |first1=Steve |title=Why John Mayer Is Music's Forgotten Superstar |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevebaltin/2017/04/22/why-john-mayer-is-musics-forgotten-superstar/ |website=Forbes |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=April 22, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181016083518/https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevebaltin/2017/04/22/why-john-mayer-is-musics-forgotten-superstar/ |archive-date=October 16, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nMayer's inclusion in the line-up of Dead & Company was criticised by [[Chris Robinson (singer)|Chris Robinson]] of [[The Black Crowes]], who had previously played several shows with The Grateful Dead. Speaking during an interview with [[Howard Stern]], Robinson was quoted as saying that \"everything that [[Jerry Garcia]] ever talked about or stood for, John Mayer is the antithesis\", and that while \"Jerry was one of the most unique musicians in the world [...] here's John Mayer playing everyone else's licks\".<ref name=\"leenewcomb\">{{cite web |last1=Lee Newcomb |first1=Ming |title=Chris Robinson Had Some Harsh Words For Both John Mayer And His Brother On Howard Stern |url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/chris-robinson-howard-stern/ |website=L4LM |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=May 16, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181016164929/https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/chris-robinson-howard-stern/ |archive-date=October 16, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> In response, Mayer said in an interview with ''Rolling Stone'' that he \"care[s] about this band too much to give that [comment] life\", and that he was \"done debating [his] own merits.\"<ref name=\"ming\">{{cite web |last1=Lee Newcomb |first1=Ming |title=John Mayer Addresses Chris Robinson's Criticisms In New Interview |url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/john-mayer-chris-robinsons-criticisms/ |website=L4LM |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=June 28, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181016164918/https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/john-mayer-chris-robinsons-criticisms/ |archive-date=October 16, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n== Personal life ==\n[[File:John_Mayer_and_Family_at_his_40th_Birthday_Dinner.pdf|thumb|alt=Alt|Mayer celebrates his 40th birthday party with (left to right) his brother Ben, his sister Rachel, his father Dick, and his brother Carl.]]\n\nOn his third episode of ''Current Mood'', Mayer revealed he had been sober since 2016.<ref name=Catucci /> He stopped drinking after having what he says was a six-day hangover after [[Drake (musician)|Drake]]'s 30th birthday party.<ref name=\"drake\">{{cite web |last1= Michaud |first1= Sarah |title= John Mayer Quit Drinking After Making 'Quite a Fool of Myself' at Drake's 30th Birthday Party |url=https://people.com/music/john-mayer-quit-drinking-after-drake-birthday-party/ |website=PEOPLE.com |access-date=November 27, 2018 |language=en |date=November 12, 2018 maintains close relationships with his father and siblings and embraces a domestic role when he is not on tour.<ref>{{cite web|last=Savino|first=Jessi|title=John Mayer Talks Life on the Road, Latest Album |url=https://huntnewsnu.com/5513/campus/john-mayer-talks-life-on-the-road-latest-album/|website=[[The Huntington News]]|access-date=July 19, 2022|date=February 3, 2007}}</ref>\n\nMayer was a friend of the late comedian and actor [[Bob Saget]], and when Saget unexpectedly died in an [[Orlando, Florida]] hotel room in January 2022, Mayer had Saget's body flown back to [[Los Angeles]] on a private jet.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.etonline.com/john-mayer-paid-for-a-private-plane-to-fly-bob-sagets-body-to-california-after-his-death-in-florida | title=John Mayer Paid for a Private Body to California | website=[[Complex Networks]] }}</ref> Likewise, he and [[Jeff Ross]] retrieved Saget's car, which was parked at [[Los Angeles International Airport]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Travis 2022}}</ref>\n\n=== Relationships ===\n<!--Please do not add any relationships to this section without a reliable source to verify it.-->\nMayer has been romantically involved with [[Jennifer Love url-status=live}}, and</ref> and [[Taylor Swift]].<ref>{{cite web |title=What Did John Mayer Do To Taylor Swift |url=https://www.distractify.com/p/what-did-john-mayer-do-to-taylor-swift |website=distractify.com |date=October 21, 2022}}</ref>{{better source needed|reason=Distractify is not a reliable source|date=July 2023}}\n\n=== Philanthropy ===\nIn 2002, Mayer created the \"Back to You\" Fund, a nonprofit organization that focuses on fundraising in the areas of health care, education, the arts and talent development. The foundation auctions exclusive John Mayer items, such as guitar picks, T-shirts and signed CDs. The auctions have been successful, with some tickets selling for more than 17 times their face value.<ref>[http://www.johnmayerauction.com/ The Official John Mayer Auction Site], John Mayer Auction. Retrieved April 23, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150131215549/http://www.johnmayerauction.com/ |date=January 31, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businesshere.com/jmayer_success.htm |title= John Mayer| work= Business Here| access-date= April 23, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204233903/http://www.businesshere.com/jmayer_success.htm |archive-date= February 4, 2007 }}</ref>\n\nMayer participated at the [[Live Earth concert, New York City|East Rutherford, New Jersey]], location of the [[Live Earth]] project, a musical rally to support awareness for [[climate change]] held July 7, 2007.<ref>{{cite news| last= Kilgore| first= Kim |year= 2007|url=http://www.livedaily.com/news/More_cities_added_to_John_Mayers_itinerary-11983.html?t=1 |title= More cities added to John Mayer's itinerary| access-date= May 1, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215114914/http://www.livedaily.com/news/More_cities_added_to_John_Mayers_itinerary-11983.html?t=1 |archive-date=February 15, 2009 }}</ref>\n\nMayer performed at a number of benefits and telethons for charity throughout his career. He has participated in benefits for the [[Elton John AIDS Foundation]].<ref>{{cite journal| last= Adato| first= Allison| display-authors= 1 | date= April 7, 2003| title= Sweet Charity| journal= People | author2= other| volume= 59| number= 13| page= 87}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last= Gardner| first= Elysa |date= November 4, 2005| title= Celebrities share Elton John's vision| work= USA Today}}</ref> In response to the [[Virginia Tech shooting]], Mayer (along with [[Dave Matthews Band]], [[Phil Vassar]], and [[Nas]]) performed a free concert at Virginia Tech's [[Lane Stadium]] on September 6, 2007.<ref name=vt.edu>{{cite web| publisher= Virginia Tech | date= August 1, 2006|url=http://www.vt.edu/concert/ |title= A Concert For Virginia Tech| website= VT.edu| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823205848/http://www.vt.edu/concert/ |archive-date= August 23, 2007 }}</ref> followed by an appearance with [[Rob Thomas (musician)|Rob Thomas]] at the Annual Holiday Concert at [[Blythedale Children's Hospital]] in Valhalla that winter.<ref>{{cite news| date= January 7, 2008| title= Fly on the wall| work= Westchester County Business Journal| volume= 47| number= 1| page= 38}}</ref> On December 8, 2007, Mayer hosted the first annual Charity Revue, a tradition he has continued each year. Charities who have benefited from the concerts include [[Toys for Tots]], Inner City Arts and the Los Angeles Mission.<ref name=announce>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnmayer.com/news#4 |title= New Show: 1st Annual Holiday Charity Revue on December 8 at Nokia Theatre LA Live| last= Mayer| first= John | website= JohnMayer.com | publisher= John Mayer| date= November 14, 2007| access-date= December 29, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226035537/http://johnmayer.com/news#4| archive-date=December 26, 2007|url-status=dead}}</ref> CDs and DVDs of the first concert were released as ''Where the Light Is'' in July 2008.<ref name=\"RS where the light is\"/><ref name=\"billboard blackberry\"/> Mayer appeared on ''[[Songs for Tibet: The Art of Peace]]'', a celebrity initiative to support [[Tibet]] and the 14th [[Dalai Lama]], [[14th Dalai Lama|Tenzin Gyatso]].<ref>{{cite news| last= Finn| first= Natalie | date= July 22, 2008|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/3342/sting-matthews-mayer-gamer-for-tibet-than-beijing |title= Sting, Matthews, Mayer Gamer for Tibet Than Beijing| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403093555/http://www.eonline.com/news/3342/sting-matthews-mayer-gamer-for-tibet-than-beijing |archive-date= April 3, 2015 | publisher= E!| website= eonline.com| access-date= March 25, 2015}}</ref> Mayer (along with Keith Urban) headlined Tiger Jam 2011 in Las Vegas to help raise around $750,000 for the [[Tiger Woods Foundation]].<ref>{{cite press release| date= May 2, 2011| title= John Mayer, Keith Urban Help Tiger Woods Raise Approximately $750,000 for the Tiger Woods Foundation at the 2011 Tiger Jam| publisher= PRNewswire}}</ref> In January 2013, Mayer participated with [[Zac Brown Band|Zac Brown]] in a benefit concert in [[Bozeman, Montana]] where they raised more than $100,000 for firefighters who battled a wildfire in the summer of 2012 in [[Paradise Valley (Montana)|Paradise Valley]] that destroyed 12,000 acres.<ref name= \"benefitconcert\"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Benoit|first=Zach|title=Pine Creek fire at 12,000 acres; at least 5 homes lost |url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/pine-creek-fire-at-acres-at-least-homes-lost/article_d8f8826d-beb7-5fbf-a43b-b76efa505246.html| work=Billings Gazette 4, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref>\n\nOn March 1, 2019, Mayer established the Heart and Armor Foundation in support of veterans of war.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heartandarmor.org/|title=Heart And Armor Foundation|website=Heartandarmor.org}}</ref> He has been actively involved in initiatives to help returning veterans for about 12 years.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Jon |last=Blistein |date=March |access-date=May 30, 2020}}</ref>\n\n===Controversies===\nMayer's relationship with Jessica Simpson coincided with behavior changes that significantly increased his [[tabloid journalism|tabloid]] exposure.<ref name=Playboy/><ref name=Mather/><ref name=ownwordsone>{{cite magazine| date= January 22, 2010 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-in-his-own-words-20100122 | title= John Mayer in His Own Words |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827131048/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-in-his-own-words-20100122 |archive-date= August 27, 2017| magazine= Rolling Stone| access-date= March 25, 2015}}</ref> Early in his career, he had expressed his resolve to completely avoid drugs, alcohol, [[Nightclub|clubbing]], \"[[Red carpet|red-carpet]]\" events, dating celebrities, and anything that he felt would detract the focus from his music.<ref name=guthrie>{{cite news| last= Guthrie| first= Blake |date= May 16, 2001|url=https://atlanta.creativeloafing.com/content-159632-Square-pegged |title= Square pegged |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204095109/http://atlanta.creativeloafing.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A4733 |archive-date=February 4, 2007 | work= Creative Loafing| access-date= February 2, 2010}}</ref> In later interviews Mayer alluded to experiencing an extreme \"anxiety bender\" episode in his twenties that motivated him to be less reclusive.<ref name=Hedegaard/><ref name=Mather/> In 2006, he first mentioned that he had begun using [[marijuana]].<ref name=\"RS06\" /> He began making appearances at clubs in Los Angeles and New York City, and Simpson became the first in a string of famous girlfriends, including [[Jennifer Aniston]] and [[Minka Kelly]].<ref name=eastland/> By 2007, his personal life had become regular fodder for the [[Tabloid journalism|gossip media]] and, as a result, Mayer made efforts to control his public image. His online presence increased,{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} he began to stage pranks for the paparazzi,<ref>{{cite journal| last= Garcia| first= Jennifer |date= June 15, 2009 |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20285171,00.html |title= John Mayer Performs, Fakes Pal's Hospital Trip| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907005741/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20285171,00.html |archive-date= September 7, 2015 | journal= People| access-date= April 28, 2015}}</ref> and he hosted a segment for the gossip show ''[[TMZ]]''.<ref>{{cite news| date= August 5, 2008|url=https://huffingtonpost.com/2008/07/28/john-mayer-guest-hosts-tm_n_115406.html |title= John Mayer TMZ Video: 'Am I Really A Celebrity?' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402121122/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/07/28/john-mayer-guest-hosts-tm_n_115406.html |archive-date= April 2, 2015 | work= Huffington Post |access-date= March 19, 2015}}</ref>\n\n{{quote box|width=350px|align=right|quote=I abused that ability to express myself, to the point where I was expressing things that weren't true to my thoughts.<ref name=patrickdoyle/>|source=John Mayer, ''Rolling Stone'' interview, January 2013}}\nIn early 2010, Mayer gave a controversial interview to ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine<ref name=outrage>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1631667/john-mayers-playboy-interview-causes-uproar-online.jhtml|title=John Mayer's Playboy Interview Causes Uproar Online|date=February 10, 2010|publisher=MTV|access-date=July 24, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629112033/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1631667/john-mayers-playboy-interview-causes-uproar-online.jhtml|archive-date=June 29, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> in which he revealed sexually explicit details about his former girlfriends Jessica Simpson and Jennifer Aniston\u2014calling his relationship with the former \"sexual napalm\".<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 12, 2010|title=John Mayer: Jessica Simpson Is \"Sexual Napalm,\" Jennifer Aniston Hates Twitter|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/john-mayer-jessica-simpso_n_456566|access-date=September 16, 2021|website=HuffPost|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Peppin|first=Hayley|title=Jessica Simpson said she was 'floored and embarrassed' after John Mayer called her 'sexual napalm'|url=https://www.insider.com/jessica-simpson-was-floored-after-john-mayer-called-her-sexual-napalm-2020-1|access-date=September 16, 2021|website=Insider|language=en-US}}</ref> In response to a question about whether black women were interested in him, he said, \"My dick is sort of like a white supremacist. I've got a Benetton heart and a fuckin' [[David Duke]] cock. I'm going to start dating separately from my dick.\"<ref name=Playboy>{{cite web|title=Playboy Interview: John Mayer|date=February 10, 2010|url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/playboy-interview-john-mayer|work=Playboy|access-date=February 10, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140831080718/http://www.playboy.com/articles/playboy-interview-john-mayer|archive-date=August 31, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> He also used the word \"[[nigger]]\" in the interview. This set off accusations in the media of him being a [[Misogyny|misogynist]], [[wikt:kiss-and-tell|kiss-and-tell]] ex-boyfriend, and [[Racism|racist]].<ref>Herrera, Monica (February 10, 2010). [https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959433/john-mayers-sexually-racially-charged-playboy-interview-sparks-outrage \"John Mayer's Sexually, Racially Charged Playboy Interview Sparks Outrage\"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130219085115/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959433/john-mayers-sexually-racially-charged-playboy-interview-sparks-outrage |date=February 19, 2013 }}. ''Billboard''. Retrieved February 10, 2010.</ref> He apologized via Twitter for his use of the word \"nigger\", saying, \"It was arrogant of me to think I could intellectualize...a word that is so emotionally charged\".<ref>Herrera, Monica (February 10, 2010), [https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959424/john-mayer-apologizes-for-using-racial-slur-in-playboy-interview \"Playboy Interview] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705104645/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959424/john-mayer-apologizes-for-using-racial-slur-in-playboy-interview |date=July 5, 2015 }}. ''Billboard''. Retrieved March 23, 2015.</ref> He also tearfully apologized to his band and fans at his concert in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] later that night.<ref>{{cite AV media | date = February 10, 2010 | title = John Mayer Cries/Apologizes in Nashville, TN 10 February 2010 Sommet Center | medium = Concert footage |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x765IhCvnqg | access-date = March 19, 2015 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017085446/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x765IhCvnqg | archive-date = October 17, 2015 | url-status=live }}</ref> In the following two years, he left New York and retreated from the media.<ref name=sniping/> Reflecting on that time in a May 2012 episode of ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'', he said: <blockquote>\"I lost my head for a little while and I did a couple of dumb interviews and it kind of woke me up...It was a violent crash into being an adult. For a couple of years, it was just figuring it all out, and I'm glad I actually stayed out of the spotlight.\"<ref name=\"ellen\">{{cite web|title=John Mayer on Taking a Break|url=http://ellen.warnerbros.com/2012/05/john_mayer_on_taking_a_break_0515.php|website=Warner Bros|access-date=June 12, 2012|date=May 15, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617205210/http://ellen.warnerbros.com/2012/05/john_mayer_on_taking_a_break_0515.php|archive-date=June 17, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Chen|first=Joyce|title=John Mayer: 'I lost my head for a while'|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-05-15/news/31714265_1_john-mayer-spotlight-interviews|work=Daily News|location=New York|access-date=June 12, 2012|date=May 15, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028212158/http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-05-15/news/31714265_1_john-mayer-spotlight-interviews|archive-date=October 28, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Koonse |first=Emma |title=John Mayer 'Lost His Head' 2 Years Ago |url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/john-mayer-lost-his-head-2-years-ago-75026/ |work=The Christian Post |access-date=June 12, 2012 |date=May 16, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406091215/http://global.christianpost.com/news/john-mayer-lost-his-head-2-years-ago-75026/ |archive-date=April 6, 2013 }}</ref></blockquote>\n\nSinger-songwriter [[Taylor Swift]] performed vocals for the song \"[[Half of My Heart]]\" on Mayer's November 2009 album ''[[Battle Studies (album)|Battle Studies]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|title=John Mayer Talks Taylor Swift Collaboration 'Half of My Heart'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1625724/john-mayer-talks-taylor-swift-collaboration-half-my-heart.jhtml|website=MTV|access-date=June 11, 2012|date=November 6, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> Rumors began to circulate in the media that the two were a couple, an assertion that neither addressed. However, Swift released a song called \"[[Dear John (Taylor Swift song)|Dear John]]\" in 2010, which was widely believed to be about her relationship with him. In June 2012, Mayer criticized the song, saying she never contacted him and that \"it's abusing your talent to rub your hands together and go, 'Wait till he gets a load of this!'\"<ref>{{cite magazine|title=John Mayer: Taylor Swift's 'Dear John' Song 'Humiliated Me'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-taylor-swifts-dear-john-song-humiliated-me-20120606|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=June 6, 2012|date=June 11, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623203359/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-taylor-swifts-dear-john-song-humiliated-me-20120606|archive-date=June 23, 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> The song \"Paper Doll\" was reported to be a [[answer song|response]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2013/06/taylor-swift-paper-doll-photos_slideshow_item0_1|title=Photos: Five Reasons to Think Taylor Swift Is John Mayer's \"Paper Doll\"|date=June 19, 2013|author=Julie Miller|magazine=Vanity Fair|access-date=August 9, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> In the March 21, 2019, episode of ''Current Mood'', however, Mayer said: <blockquote>\"When 'Paper Doll' came out, 100% of the people believed it was about somebody...But the song was not about that person and I could never tell anybody, 'That's not true,' because then I would be breaking my rule that songwriters don't say who the songs are about or not about.\"<ref>{{cite AV media | people =JOhn Mayer | date =March 21, 2019 | title =Current Mood from Brisbane, Australia\u2014John Mayer World Tour 2019 | medium =webshow | time =23m40s | location =Brisbane, Australia | publisher =Instagram }}</ref></blockquote>\n\nIn March 2014, Mayer sued watch dealer Robert Maron for $656,000 when he discovered that seven of the $5 million in watches he purchased from the dealer contained counterfeit parts.<ref>''People'' staff (March 29, 2014), \"THE Action\". ''Billboard''. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Chris_Marion","to":"Chris Marion"}],"pages":{"5514499":{"pageid":5514499,"ns":0,"title":"Chris Marion","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American musician (born 1962)}}\n{{More footnotes|date=November 2021}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name            = '''Chris Marion'''\n| image           = Chris_marion.jpg\n| caption         =\n| image_size      = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels -->\n| birth_name      =\n| alias           =\n| birth_date      = {{birth date and age|1962|1|8}}\n| origin          = [[Belton, Texas|Belton]], [[Texas]], U.S.\n| instrument      = [[Vocals]], [[Keyboard instrument|keyboards]]\n| genre           = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Gospel music|gospel]]\n| occupation      =\n| years_active    = 1976\u2013present\n| label           =\n| associated_acts = [[Little River Band]], [[Western Flyer]]\n| website         = {{URL|chrismarionmusic.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Chris Marion''' (born January 8, 1962) is an American [[musician]] best known as a member of the [[Little River Band]] and for his contribution to the [[rock music|rock]] and [[gospel music]] industries.\nBorn in [[Belton, Texas]], and growing up in rural [[Virginia]], Marion started his musical career as a pianist for his traveling family gospel group.  He started taking piano lessons at age four and continued classical training on piano, trombone, and voice through college.\n\n==Early life==\nAfter graduating with honors from [[Chilhowie]] High School in 1980, Marion pursued a degree in music at [[Carson-Newman College]] in [[Jefferson City, Tennessee]]. He eventually graduated with a degree in psychology. It was during his time at Carson Newman that he developed the relationships that led him to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue music professionally.\n\n==Career==\nSince moving to Nashville in 1987, Marion has toured with the likes of [[Steven Curtis Chapman]], [[Shenandoah (band)|Shenandoah]], [[Beth Moore]] and [[Jeannie Seely]] of the [[Grand Ole Opry]]. In 1994, along with Danny Myrick, Marion founded the country rock band [[Western Flyer]] on the Step One Record label which garnered four charting ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' singles in the country genre along with critical praise.\n\nAs the writer and producer of a variety of children's musical projects, Marion has received 4 [[Gospel Music Association]] [[Dove Award]] nominations.  He has been involved in projects involving [[LifeWay Christian Resources]] VBS and other religious products for [[Word Records]], [[Benson Records]] and others.  As a producer, Marion was part of a team that worked with [[Garth Brooks]], [[Doug Stone]], the [[Oak Ridge Boys]] and [[Charlie Chase (broadcaster)|Charlie Chase]].\n\nAt the end of 2004, Marion was invited to join [[Little River Band]] in which he is the [[keyboardist]] and a vocalist.\n\nIn 2011, Marion founded TourPRO, a touring personnel resource that facilitates personnel placement with artists and tours.\n\nIn 2013, Marion joined the editorial team at [[Harmony Central]], a weekly e-magazine that features articles about the music industry, gear reviews, artist interviews and discussion forums.\n\nIn 2020, Marion married Stephanie Calvert of the band [[Starship (band)|Starship]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Chris Marion & Stephanie Calvert|url=https://registry.theknot.com/chris-marion-stephanie--calvert--january-2020-hi/33856017|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211118063548/https://registry.theknot.com/chris-marion-stephanie--calvert--january-2020-hi/33856017 |archive-date=2021-11-18 }}</ref> During their COVID-19 band hiatuses, they formed a duo, the B-Listers, with limited North American touring coordinating with the touring schedules of their respective bands.<ref>{{Cite web|last=B-Listers|first=The|title=The B-Listers - Band, Musician|url=https://theb-listers.com/|access-date=2021-11-18|website=The B-Listers|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\nIn 2023, Marion was honored with a Triumph Award from his alma mater, [[Carson Newman University]] for distinguished achievement in Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cn.edu/c-n-celebrates-outstanding-alumni-during-annual-awards-ceremony/|title=C-N celebrates outstanding alumni during Annual Awards Ceremony|first=Marketing and|last=Communications|date=October 25, 2023|website=Carson-Newman University}}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n{| This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Drew_Davis_Band","to":"Drew Davis Band"}],"pages":{"15439501":{"pageid":15439501,"ns":0,"title":"Drew Davis Band","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American musical group}}\n{{use American English|date=September 2024}}\n{{use mdy|date=September 2024}}\n{{one source|date=April 2020}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Drew Davis Band\n| image             = \n| caption           = \n| image_size        = \n| origin            = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]\n| genre             = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Country music|country]]\n| years_active      = 2001\u20132010\n| label             = Windswept, 903, [[Lofton Creek Records|Lofton Creek]]\n| past_members      = Drew Davis<br/> Mike Drake<br/> Loren Ellis<br/> Jay Hawks<br/> Mo Levone<br/> Roger Malinowski\n}}\n\nThe '''Drew Davis Band''' was an American [[Rock music|rock]], [[country music]] group established in 2001 by Drew Davis ([[lead vocals]], [[guitar]]), Mike Drake (guitar, [[harmonica]], [[fiddle]]), Loren Ellis ([[banjo]], guitar, [[mandolin]], vocals), Jay Hawks ([[Drum kit|drums]]), Mo Levone ([[bass guitar]], vocals), and Roger Malinkowski (keyboards).<ref name=\"cmt\">{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/davis__drew/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080927071633/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/davis__drew/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 27, 2008 |title=The Drew Davis Band biography |accessdate=2008-01-26 |work=[[Country Music Television]]}}</ref>\n\nIn 2004, the band competed in and won the [[Colgate Country Showdown]]; shortly afterward, they were signed to Windswept Publishing, with a self-titled EP being released that year. Eventually, they were transferred to 903 Music, a short-lived record label founded by [[Neal McCoy]]; upon the label's closure in 2007, the band was transferred to [[Lofton Creek Records]]. Both Mike Drake and Jay Hawks have since left the group. The band's debut single, \"Back There All the Time\", entered the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. It was included on both their self-titled EP and on their 2008 album ''Crossroads''. Roger Malinowski left the band in 2009 to be David Spade's stuntman.\n\nThe Drew Davis Band was featured on an episode of ''[[Gene Simmons Family Jewels]]'' on August 9, 2009.  The episode also featured a guest appearance by [[Trace Adkins]]. They also performed the theme song for the [[Disney Channel]] series ''[[Phil of the Future]]'' and ''[[The Suite Life of Zack & Cody]]''.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Crossroads''\n| \n* Release date: July 8, 2008\n* Label: DELM Records\n|}\n\n===Extended plays===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! style=\"width:12em;\"| Title\n! style=\"width:18em;\"| Album details\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| ''Drew Davis Band'' EP\n| \n* Release date: October 4, 2005\n* Label: Windswept Records\n|}\n\n===Singles===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\" style=\"text-align:center;\"\n|-\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Year\n! rowspan=\"2\" style=\"width:18em;\"| Single\n! colspan=\"1\"| Peak positions\n! rowspan=\"2\"| Album\n|- style=\"font-size:smaller;\"\n! width=\"60\"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]\n|-\n| 2005\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Back There All the Time\"\n| \u2014\n| align=\"left\"| ''Drew Davis Band'' EP\n|-\n| rowspan=\"2\"| 2008\n! scope=\"row\"| \"Back There All the Time\" <small>(re-release)</small>\n| 58\n| align=\"left\" rowspan=\"2\"| ''Crossroads''\n|-\n! scope=\"row\"| \"How Do I\"\n| \u2014\n|-\n| colspan=\"4\" style=\"font-size:8pt\"| \"\u2014\" denotes releases that did not chart\n|-\n|}\n\n===Music videos===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n! This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Leon_Russell","to":"Leon Russell"}],"pages":{"820867":{"pageid":820867,"ns":0,"title":"Leon Russell","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1942\u20132016)}}\n{{Use American English|date=May 2023}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2021}}\n{{Infobox person\n| name          = Leon Russell\n| image         = Leon Russell Billboard.jpg\n| caption       = Russell {{circa}} 1970\n| birth_name    = Claude Russell Bridges\n| alias         = Hank Wilson, Russell Bridges, C. J. Russell, Lew Russell\n| birth_date    = {{birth date|mf=y|1942|04|02}}\n| birth_place   = [[Lawton, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n| death_date    = {{death date and age|mf=y|2016|11|13|1942|04|02}}\n| death_place   = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| burial_place = Memorial Park Cemetery in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n| spouse        = {{plainlist|\n* {{marriage|[[Mary McCreary]]|20 June 1975|3 October 1980}}<ref>{{cite web |last=Aronowitz |first=Al |title=Leon Russell Dead at 74 |url=https://www.blacklistedjournalist.com/column56a.html |website=blacklistedjournalist.com |publisher=The Blacklisted Journalist |access-date=August 29, 2024}}</ref>\n* {{marriage|Janet Lee Constantine|1983|2016}}<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stefano |first1=Angela |title=Leon Russell Dead at 74 |url=https://kkyr.com/leon-russell-dead-dies/ |website=kkyr.com |date=November 13, 2016 |publisher=Townsquare Media, Inc. |access-date=22 August 2024}}</ref>\n}}\n| children      = 6\n| occupation    = Musician, arranger, conductor, record producer, record executive, singer-songwriter\n| years_active  = 1956\u20132016\n\n| module        = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes\n| label         = {{hlist|Viva|Olympic Records|Perspective Sound|Robbins|[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]|[[Shelter Records|Shelter]]|[[Paradise Records|Paradise]]|Leon Russell Records|[[Virgin Records]]|[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]}}\n| associated_acts  = {{hlist|[[J. J. Cale]]|[[Marc Benno]]|[[New Grass Revival]]|[[George Harrison]]|[[Bob Dylan]]|[[Eric Clapton]]|[[Willie Nelson]]|[[Neil Young]]|[[Elton John]]|[[Rita Coolidge]]|[[Joe Cocker]]|[[Edgar Winter]]|[[The Wrecking Crew (music)|The Wrecking Crew]]}}\n| instrument       = {{hlist|Keyboards|vocals|bass guitar|guitar|baritone horn}}\n| genre            = {{flatlist|* [[Rock music|Rock]]\n* [[Country music|country]]\n* [[gospel music|gospel]]\n* [[rhythm and blues|R&B]]\n}}\n| background       = solo_singer\n| website = {{URL|leonrussell.com}}\n}}\n}}\n\n'''Leon Russell''' (born '''Claude Russell Bridges'''; April 2, 1942 \u2013 November 13, 2016) was an American musician and songwriter who was involved with numerous bestselling records during his 60-year career that spanned multiple genres, including [[rock and roll]],<ref name=Guardian/> [[Country music|country]], [[Gospel music|gospel]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[rhythm and blues]], [[southern rock]],<ref name=Chappell/> [[blues rock]],<ref name=CBS/> [[Folk music|folk]], [[surf music|surf]] and the [[Tulsa sound]]. His recordings earned six [[Music recording certification|gold record]]s and he received two [[Grammy Awards]] from seven nominations. In 1973 ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' named Russell the \"Top Concert Attraction in the World\".<ref name=TopConcertAttraction>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/leon-russell-legendary-songwriter-and-performer-dies-at-74-7573584/ | title=Leon Russell, Legendary Songwriter and Performer, Dies at 74 | website=Billboard.com | access-date=June 2, 2024}}</ref> In 2011, he was inducted into both the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] and the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Leon Russell Biography |url=http://www.biography.com/people/leon-russell |url-status=dead |website=Biography.com |access-date=March 14, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170422202336/http://www.biography.com/people/leon-russell |archive-date=April 22, 2017}}</ref>\n\nRussell collaborated with many notable artists and recorded 33 albums and 430 songs.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thechurchstudio.com/about/leon-russell/ | title=Who Is Leon Russell?|date=January 6, 2023 |access-date=May 26, 2024}}</ref> He wrote \"Delta Lady\", recorded by [[Joe Cocker]], and organized and performed with Cocker's ''[[Mad Dogs & Englishmen (album)|Mad Dogs & Englishmen]]'' tour in 1970. His \"[[A Song for You]]\", which was named to the [[Grammy Hall of Fame]] in 2018, has been recorded by more than 200 artists, and his song \"[[This Masquerade]]\" by more than 75.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Nashville-Related Music Obituaries 2016 | url=https://www.musicrow.com/2017/01/nashville-related-music-obituaries-2016/ |magazine=[[MusicRow]] |date=January 4, 2017 |access-date=March 14, 2017}}</ref>\n\nAs a pianist, Russell played in his early years on albums by [[the Beach Boys]], [[The Ventures]], [[Dick Dale]], and [[Jan and Dean]]. On his first album, ''[[Leon Russell (album)|Leon Russell]]'', in 1970, the musicians included [[Eric Clapton]], [[Ringo Starr]], and [[George Harrison]]. One of his early fans, [[Elton John]], said that Russell was a \"mentor\" and an \"inspiration\".<ref>{{cite web |title=In Honor of Leon Russell (1942\u20132016) |url=https://www.eltonjohn.com/stories/in-honor-of-leon-russell-1942-2016 |url-status=live |access-date=March 14, 2020 |website=EltonJohn.com |date=November 17, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200127055511/https://www.eltonjohn.com/stories/in-honor-of-leon-russell-1942-2016 |archive-date=January 27, 2020}}</ref> They recorded their album ''[[The Union (Elton John and Leon Russell album)|The Union]]'' in 2010, earning them a Grammy nomination.\n\nRussell produced and played in recording sessions for [[Bob Dylan]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Ike & Tina Turner]], [[the Rolling Stones]], and many other artists. He wrote and recorded the hits \"[[Tight Rope (song)|Tight Rope]]\" and \"[[Lady Blue (song)|Lady Blue]]\". He performed at [[The Concert for Bangladesh]] in 1971, along with Harrison, Dylan, and Clapton; for this he earned a Grammy Award.\n\n==Early life and education==\nRussell was born on April 2, 1942, the second of John Griffith and Hester Evel (n\u00e9e Whaley) Bridges' two sons at Southwestern Hospital in [[Lawton, Oklahoma]].<ref name=\"Master\">{{cite book | author=Bill Janovitz | year=2023 | title=Leon Russell: The Master of Space and Time's Journey Through Rock & Roll History | publisher=Hachette Books}}</ref><ref name=\"NYT-2016\">{{cite news |last=Pareles |first=John |title=Leon Russell, Hit Maker and Musicians' Musician, Dies at 74 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/14/arts/music/leon-russell-hit-maker-and-musicians-musician-dies-at-74.html?_r=0 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 13, 2016 |access-date=November 15, 2016}}</ref> Russell's mother said he started talking later than most children. She said while he was \"watching the birds, and something was going on with the birds\", Russell's first words were \"What's the matter little birdie, you cry?\". Russell's mother said \"she was shocked, because he never spoke\".<ref name=\"Master\"/> Russell said he \"was born with 'spastic paralysis', now called [[cerebral palsy]]\". An injury at birth had damaged his second and third vertebrae, causing a slight paralysis in the right side of his body, most notably affecting three fingers on his right hand. This caused Russell to favor his left hand and develop his signature left-hand-dominant piano playing style.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thechurchstudio.com/about/leon-russell/ | author=Nancy Ruth | title=Leon Russell: The Early Childhood Years|date=January 6, 2023 |access-date=May 26, 2024}}</ref> He said \"My chops have always been sort of weak ... I have damaged nerve endings on the right side, so my piano style comes from designing stuff I can play with my right hand\". Russell said the condition helped him become \"very aware of the duality involved in our plane of existence here\".<ref name=\"Space and Time\">{{cite web | url=https://www.leonrussell.com/the-early-years| title=Leon Russell Master of Space and Time | website=Leon Russell Master of Space and Time| access-date=May 26, 2024 }}</ref> Russell also had a limp caused by the same condition that was once thought due to polio. He said \"I felt like the world had cheated me big time\" but added \"If I hadn't had the problem, I probably wouldn't have gotten into music at all and would have been an ex-football player, selling insurance in Des Moines\".<ref name=\"Space and Time\"/>\n\nBoth of Russell's parents played upright piano and at age four, Russell's mother heard him picking out the melody to \"Trust and Obey\", a hymn he had heard at church. He then began piano lessons in [[Anadarko, Oklahoma|Anadarko]], a 38 mile trip to and from the family home. While still taking piano lessons, Russell learned the alto saxophone and cornet in his elementary school band.<ref name=\"Master\"/> He then learned to play the baritone horn. After impressing the Maysville High School band director, Russell was invited to join the high school marching band while in the fifth grade.<ref name=\"thechurchstudio\">{{cite web |url=https://thechurchstudio.com/leon-russell-childhood | author=Nancy Ruth | title=Leon Russell: The Early Childhood Years|date=January 6, 2023 |access-date=May 26, 2024}}</ref> Russell said he learned to fake a classical piano style, saying \"I studied classical music for a long time, maybe ten years, and I realized, finally, I was never going to have the hands to play that stuff. It was too complicated. I invented ways to play in a classical style that was not the real deal\".<ref name=Alpert1>{{cite web | url=https://www.vinyl-magic.com/blog/leon-russell-erin-and-me | title=Leon Russell, Erin and Me\u2026. | publisher=Neil Kirk | date=April 3, 2023 | access-date=June 10, 2024}}</ref>  \n\n[[File:Claude Russell Bridges (Leon Russell) (1958 yearbook portrait).jpg|thumb|left|Claude Russell Bridges 1958 Will Rogers High School yearbook photo]]\n\n===High school===\nRussell attended [[Will Rogers High School]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]. His classmates included [[Elvin Bishop]], [[Anita Bryant]] and [[David Gates]]. His first record appearance was in 1957 age 15 years old, when he played piano on \"Jo-Baby\", a song written by 16 year-old Gates. Originally attributed to \"The Accents\" it was released on the Tulsa-based Perspective Sound label then re-released a year later and distributed nationally by [[Marty Robbins]] on his Robbins Records record label under the band name \"David Gates & The Accents\".<ref name=\"thechurchstudio\"/> Russell would later collaborate with Gates after high school in the band The Fencemen.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://beat-magazine.co.uk/2013/jfs-memory-time-machine-leon-russel |title=JF's Memory Time Machine: Leon Russel &#124; Beat Magazine |access-date=January 7, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221013624/http://beat-magazine.co.uk/2013/jfs-memory-time-machine-leon-russel |archive-date=December 21, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref>\nRussell credited his awareness of the precursors of American soul music to a homemade AM crystal radio. <ref name=LA1>{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Randy |date=October 7, 2010 |title=Leon Russell on Elton John, crystal radio sets, and playing piano for Phil Spector |url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/blogs/pop-hiss/story/2010-10-07/leon-russell-on-elton-john-crystal-radio-sets-and-playing-piano-for-phil-spector |work=Los Angeles Times |location=Los Angeles, California |access-date=June 6, 2024}}</ref> He was offered a chance to tour with [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] after graduating. Explaining his decision to not attend college, Russell said, \"I figured this was my chance to eat in a lot of restaurants and travel around, play some rock and roll music, which I decided was easier and better\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/leon-russell-renowned-songwriter-and-musician-dead-at-74-114918/ | title=Leon Russell, Renowned Songwriter and Musician, Dead at 74 | website=RollingStone.com | date=November 13, 2016 | access-date=May 27, 2024}}</ref>\n\n\nPerforming while underage in clubs and bars, Russell assumed the name \"Leon Russell\" from a fake ID card he used to enter clubs even though he was a high school student. At the time, Oklahoma was a \"dry\" state, so teenagers were able to perform in clubs that ordinarily would have only been open to those over 21 years of age.<ref name=\"Space and Time\"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.oklahomahof.com/hof/inductees/leon-russell| title=Leon Russell | website=Oklahoma Hall of Fame| access-date=May 26, 2024 }}</ref>\n\nAlthough still in high school, Russell performed at area supper clubs, bars and nightclubs with his group \"The Starlighters\" (Russell, [[J.J. Cale]], Leo Feathers, Johnny Williams, and Chuck Blackwell). Blackwell said Russell was \"...especially good at playing [[Erroll Garner]]-style jazz during dinner, but then, after everybody got through eating, he'd break into [[Jerry Lee Lewis]]\".<ref name=\"Master\"/> Russell also backed groups in Tulsa including [[Ronnie Hawkins]] and [[The Band|The Hawks]], often until early morning, after having worked through the night.<ref name=\"thechurchstudio\"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.willrogers1959.com/files/John_Williams_article_3-31-02.pdf | title=Come blow your horn | website=Willrogers1959.com | access-date=December 14, 2015 | archive-date=March 4, 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304100924/http://www.willrogers1959.com/files/John_Williams_article_3-31-02.pdf | url-status=dead }}</ref> Russell said \"I worked six or seven nights a week till I left Tulsa at 17. I'd work 6 to 11 (pm) at a beer joint, then 1 to 5 (am) at an after-hours club. It was a hard schedule to do when going to school. I slept in English a lot\".<ref name=\"LateNight\">{{cite web |last=Conner |first=Thomas |date=May 1, 1998 |title=Leon Russell founded Shelter Records in the '70s and, with it, a local scene|url=https://www.thomasconner.info/clips/leon-russell-founded-shelter-records-in-the-70s-and-with-it-a-local-scene |access-date=June 3, 2024 |work=thomasconner.info |publisher=Tulsa World}}</ref>\n\n===Los Angeles===\nRussell said \"...I got out to California, and they were more serious about their liquor laws. I about starved to death because it was so much harder to find work at my age\".<ref name=\"LateNight\"/> Settling in Los Angeles, he studied guitar with [[James Burton]].\n\nRussell was primarily a session musician in his early career. During session work he played for and with artists as varied as [[Jan and Dean]], [[Ricky Nelson]], [[Gary Lewis & the Playboys]], [[George Harrison]], [[Delaney Bramlett]], [[Freddy Cannon]], [[Ringo Starr]], [[Doris Day]], [[Elton John]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[the Byrds]], [[Barbra Streisand]], [[the Beach Boys]], [[the Ventures]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Badfinger]], the [[Herb Alpert|Tijuana Brass]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[the Band]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[J. J. Cale]], [[B.B. King]],<ref>Liner notes. B. B. King, ''Indianola Mississippi Seeds''. ABC Dunhill Records.</ref> [[Dave Mason]], [[Glen Campbell]], [[Lynn Anderson]], [[Joe Cocker]], [[the Rolling Stones]], and [[the Flying Burrito Brothers]].<ref name=\"The Great Rock Discography\">{{cite book | author=Martin C. Strong | year=2000 | title=The Great Rock Discography | edition=5th | publisher=Mojo Books | location=Edinburgh | pages=838\u2013839 | isbn=1-84195-017-3}}</ref>\n\nAs Russell developed his solo artist career, he crossed genres to include [[rock and roll]], [[blues]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and [[gospel music]].\n\n==1960s - Session musician, solo artist, record executive==\n\nIn Los Angeles, Russell played as a studio musician on many of the popular songs of the 1960s, including the Byrds, [[Gary Lewis & the Playboys]], [[Bobby Pickett]], and [[Herb Alpert]]. He also played piano on [[Phil Spector]] productions, including recordings by [[the Ronettes]], [[the Crystals]], and [[Darlene Love]] and in the 1963 ''[[A Christmas Gift for You from Phil Spector]]'' album. \n\nHerb Alpert said of Russell, \"Leon was on several sessions that I produced with the Tijuana Brass. He was always dressed in a suit and tie, with short hair and no beard! This was soon after he arrived in Los Angeles from Oklahoma. We would go through the same routine each time I started rehearsing the music. He would sit at the piano and he would always say, 'I don\u2019t know what to play'. And I would say, 'Just wait and see if you feel something, and if you don\u2019t it\u2019s okay. I just like your energy at the sessions'. Well, he would always chime in with something special and affect the groove in a very Leon Russell way that was always unique. Leon was a wonderful musician and had a major effect on all of my recordings. His touch can be heard on many Tijuana Brass records, including \"Whipped Cream\" and \"A Taste of Honey\". To top it off, Leon was a true gentleman with a special talent and he was a person that I had a great feeling for\".<ref name=Alpert1/> In 1962 Russell played piano on [[Walter Brennan]]'s lp ''Old Rivers'', produced by Snuff Garrett. Garrett said \"I could talk style with him (Russell) and he'd do it. I'd name a record. I'd go, 'I like the piano on this... and he'd go, 'Okay', and do the piano part... I fell in love with his playing\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tapeop.com/interviews/73/tommy-snuff-garrett/ | title=Tommy \"Snuff\" Garrett: A Cowboy in the Control Room | publisher=tapeop.com|author=Larry Crane | access-date=August 31, 2024}}</ref>\n\nCredited as Russell Bridges, he contributed to the Canadian Sweethearts' ([[Bob Regan]] and [[Lucille Starr]]) first A&M Records recording session with [[Dorsey Burnette]] in 1963. The lp ''Introducing The Canadian Sweethearts'' was released in 1964.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.onamrecords.com/artists/canadian-sweethearts | title=CANADIAN SWEETHEARTS | publisher=Leslie J. Pfenninger | access-date=August 31, 2024}}</ref> Glen Campbell's 1967 album ''[[Gentle on My Mind (1967 Glen Campbell album)|Gentle on My Mind]]'' credited him as Russell Bridges on piano.<ref>{{cite web | author=Joe Marchese | url=http://theseconddisc.com/2011/06/24/gentle-on-his-mind-two-early-glen-campbell-classics-reissued-by-bgo/ | title=Gentle on His Mind: Two Early Glen Campbell Classics Reissued by BGO | publisher=The Second Disc | date=June 24, 2011 | access-date=December 14, 2015}}</ref>\n\n===Early media appearances===\nIn 1962 a 20 year-old Russell appeared on Los Angeles TV station [[KCOP]] leading The Leon Russell Trio on the rock 'n' roll show ''Stepping Out''. Airing at 11:00 at night, the live broadcast often aired multiple times per week.<ref>{{cite news |date=September 9, 1962 |title=Wednesday |url=https://www.newspaperarchive.com/us/california/long-beach/long-beach-independent/1962/09-09/page-112 |url-status=live |work=Long Beach Independent |location=Long Beach, California  |access-date=August 30, 2024}}</ref> He can also be seen in the 1964 concert film ''[[T.A.M.I. Show]]'' playing piano with [[The Wrecking Crew (music)|the Wrecking Crew]], sporting short, dark, slicked-back hair, in contrast to his later look.<ref name=\"The Great Rock Discography\"/>\n\n===Early recordings===\nIn 1962 a 20 year-old Russell once again collaborated with David Gates, releasing the 45 rpm single \"Sad September / Tryin\u2019 To Be Someone\" which featured session guitarist [[James Burton]]. Credited to David & Lee and later to Dave & Lee, the record was produced by [[Gary S. Paxton|Gary Paxton]] and first released on Paxton's G.S.P. Records label.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.fretboardjournal.com/columns/guitarist-center-american-music-james-burton-early-years-1956-1969/ | title=The Guitarist at the Center of American Music: James Burton: The Early Years, 1956-1969 | author=John Thomas| date=January 2012 | access-date=August 31, 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nhpr.org/2012-05-25/james-burton-the-teen-who-invented-american-guitar | title=James Burton: The Teen Who Invented American Guitar | author=Ed Ward| date=May 25, 2012 | access-date=August 31, 2024}}</ref>\n\n===Composer===\nIn the mid-1960s, he wrote or co-wrote songs, including two hits for Gary Lewis and the Playboys: \"[[Everybody Loves a Clown (song)|Everybody Loves a Clown]]\" (which reached the ''Billboard'' Top 40 on October 9, 1965, remaining on the chart for eight weeks and reaching number 4) and \"[[She's Just My Style]]\" (which entered the ''Billboard'' Top 40 on December 18, 1965, and rose to number 3).<ref>See Whitburn, Joel (1992). ''The Billboard Book of Top 40 Hits''. 5th ed. Billboard Books. p. 275. {{ISBN|978-0823082803}}.</ref> \n\n===Hired by Snuff Garrett===\nRussell was hired by [[Snuff Garrett]] and together they formed a production company, Snuff Garrett Productions in 1964. Russell was a production assistant, arranger and creative developer for the company.<ref name=\"Space and Time\"/> Russell played on many number-one singles, including \"[[This Diamond Ring]]\" by Gary Lewis & the Playboys.<ref>''Billboard'', March 4, 1967, and December 15, 1973, p. 37.</ref> Russell also acted as Garrett's arranger and conductor of the [[Midnight String Quartet]]'s debut album ''Rhapsodies For Young Lovers''. The album was planned as a solo Leon Russell lp, but was instead marketed as a Midnight String Quartet production.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/rhapsodies-for-young-lovers-mw0000497944/credits | title=Rhapsodies for Young Lovers \u2013 Midnight String Quartet &#124; Credits | website=[[AllMusic]] | date=October 16, 2007 | access-date=December 14, 2015}}</ref>\n\nRussell and [[Al Capps]] arranged [[Brian Hyland]]'s 1966 single \"[[The Joker Went Wild]]\", written by [[Bobby Russell]] (no relation to Leon). Russell also played xylophone and bells on the record.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.mcall.com/2017/10/26/american-bandstand-singers-coming-to-easton-talk-about-why-their-songs-have-staying-power/ | title=American Bandstand singers, coming to Easton, talk about why their songs have staying power | author=John J. Moser| website=mcall.com | date=October 26, 2017 }}</ref> Jason Ankeny of [[AllMusic]] said \"Russell's evocative arrangements lend 'The Joker Went Wild' much of its appeal, however, channeling the lessons of Phil Spector and Brian Wilson to create rich, bold pop far greater than the sum of its parts\".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-joker-went-wild-run-run-look-and-see-mw0001012971 | title=The Joker Went Wild / Run, Run, Look and See | author= Jason Ankeny| website=allmusic.com }}</ref> The track reached #20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref>[https://musicvf.com/song.php?title=The+Joker+Went+Wild+by+Brian+Hyland&id=6910 Brian Hyland, \"The Joker Went Wild\" Chart Position] Retrieved April 25, 2023</ref>\n\nTwo years later, Garrett and Russell started Viva Records. Russell was the record label's initial [[Artists and repertoire|A&R]] representative as well as producer for many of the label's recordings, including The Shindogs' 1966 \"Who Do You Think You Are / Yes, I\u2019m Going Home\" (Viva V-601).
